description.text: dock simple
This is an iPad stand made with dowels, vinyl tubing, nuts and bolts, zip ties and two small 3D printed parts.

To make the frame, it's easiest to make the outer part, first.  Since the triangle that the ipad rests on which rests inside the outer part, you can sorta do the design on the fly.  After putting the frame together, print a couple of the included nubs and slip them on to the lower dowel.  Hot glue them for security. 
I've included an STL for the nubs that fit dowels that are 15.5mm diameter.

comments.text: You could use a Makerbot to make a center joint capable of taking 5 dowels and another making 6, and make a small geodesic dome or sphere.Â  Dowels run as long as 3 1/2 feet, so your geodesic sphere or domeÂ could be used as a tent skeleton.

description.text:
Slapped a paint shaker for my acrylic Paints together.
Additionally to the printed parts you need:
1x M8x40 Hex Shaft Bolt (or longer)
2x M8 Washers
1x M8 Nut (Selflocking recommended)
1x M5x30 Shaft Bolt (or longer) --> gets directly screwed into the plastic
2x M5 Washers

You hook up an electrical drill to the open end of the M8 Bolt and voila, your paints almost shake themselves.

Note of caution: The stl files are not positioned properly when imported into your slicer, you need to lay them flat on the bed to print properly! (As seen in one of the pictures)

Update: Vertical Version:
New Parts for the Vertical Version are all marked "Vertikal", rest is the same as in the swinging action one.

print_settings.Notes:: Length of the jig is 370 mm (14.6 inch). In order to print it even on smaller machines and for better fit into my toolbox it's divided into 2 parts of 192.5 mm (7.6 inch) with locking feature.

description.text:
This jig provides a drilling pattern for mounting Salomon's cross-country bindings. Salomon claims that all of his products has same screw placement so it should work either with SNS and Prolink. I've tested it so far only with SNS Pilot Equipe CL binding.
You can use it either only for marking the screw-hole positions (freehand drilling). However it is more convenient to use the jig as a guide for your drill bit.

Using procedure:
1) Put masking tape on the top of your skies (optional / you can draw directly on the ski)
2) Find your balance point and mark that line.
3) Draw a centre line (optional - centring of jig is easy by eyeballing)
4) Attach a jig using clamps or tape carefully
5) Find a 3.5 mm drillbit and mark required depth of holes from the tip using tape. The depth is length of threaded part of screw plus 5 mm for the thickness of jig. Put it into a drill chuck.
6) Drill all 5 holes
7) Remove jig, tape and clean everything
8) Mount the binding. Don't forget to put a little of glue (woodglue, epoxy) to the holes to prevent water penetrating the ski.
9) Repeat for the other ski and you're DONE!

Very nice how to manual (not mine) can be found here:
http://therecreationalist.com/how-to-mount-cross-country-ski-bindings/

Skol!

Stratasys

Printer:

Fortus 400mc

No

spare

Notes:

Length of the jig is 370 mm (14.6 inch). In order to print it even on smaller machines and for better fit into my toolbox it's divided into 2 parts of 192.5 mm (7.6 inch) with locking feature.
Like the original, but with wider hole for the z axis to prevent jams

title: Brille für optische Gläser - optical glasses
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
For English please use Google translate.

Brille für richtige optische Gläser, die beim Optiker eingeschliffen werden.

Mein altes Brillengestell ist leider kaputt gegangen. Was tun mit den Gläsern? Klar, da muss was Gedrucktes her! Ich habe es mit Sketchup erstellt und muss sagen, dass ich wohl die Grenze des Programms erreicht habe. Das ein oder andere Mal war es dann wohl auch zuviel, Sketchup hat sich mitten drin einfach verabschiedet und die letzten Ausbesserungen gingen verloren. Habe es aber schliesslich geschafft.

Den Bügel habe ich nur einmal hier, das Gegenstück muss einfach gespiegelt werden.
Zusätzlich werden 4 Schrauben M2 x 10 für den Zusammenbau benötigt.

Ich habe mit einer Layerhöhe von 0,1mm mit PLA gedruckt.
Die Schraubenlöcher der Bügel sollten soweit ausgefeilt werden biss die Schraube frei drehen kann. In die Löcher im Gestell fressen sich die Schrauben selbst ein Gewinde beim reindrehen.
Die Nut für die Gläser muss absolut glatt sein.
Die flachen Ecken an den Außenseiten des Gestells dienen nur der besseren Haftung beim Druck und müssen hinterher weggeschnitten werden. Ein kompletter Brim ist an den Rändern des Gestells nur sehr schwer zu entfernen.

description.text:
I needed a handy box to store the playingcards for my kids.

i uploaded the .scad file which can be paramitrised for your own purpose.

if you do not have OpenSCAD, feel free to ask and i will upload a .stl file with your needed dimensions.

Parameters are:

$fn=100;

// Size of the content you want to store (i would recomend to add a "inner tolerance" as well)
inner_tolerance = 0.0;
size = [50.5 + inner_tolerance, 33.5 + inner_tolerance, 25 + inner_tolerance];
// Wall thickness
wall_thickness=2;
// width of the whole where you can stick your fingers in
inner_whole=20;
// the distance between the top and the bottom box
tolerance=0.5;
Get your Psychobilly on even in the afterlife!

title: Prusa i3 MK3 Raspberry Pi Camera Bed Mount

description.text:
This is a Raspberry Pi Camera mount for the Prusa i3 MK3. There are already a few designs on Thingiverse for the MK3 but I thought I tinker a bit. In the end I designed something completely from scratch.

This version snaps onto the bed Y-carriage of the MK3 - it has a slot that fits perfectly around the carriage. You only need one zip-tie to avoid the piece sliding off the Y-carriage and in order to fix it even more tight. Another slot is provided for the ribbon cable of the camera. If you want you can use some extra zip-ties to guide the ribbon cable a bit towards the printer.

I have made an 45 degree angled version and a straight version as well as a left and right version. The angled versions make sure the camera mount is parallel to the bed.

The Pi camera I use is a wide angle (fish eye) version and a case for this is provided as well. The case has a recess for the ball and is snug enough to make sure the camera does not rotate or tilt while printing. If you do not have a wide angle camera, I am sure there are enough alternatives on Thingiverse to be found.

You will have to print this with supports (it will be minimal supports, just for the slot snapping to the Y-carriage). I printed these in ABS and in PETG; note that with ABS it is easier to remove the supports than with PETG.

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

i3 MK3

No

Supports:

Yes

0.2

min 40%

remixed_from.title: Star Wars Rose’s Rebel Alliance Iris Ring

description.text:
This is a generalized remix of my design of Rose’s Rebel Alliance iris ring from The Last Jedi. I wanted to make a hidden symbol iris ring that people can customize and put the symbol of their choice at the center.

I made an instructional video on how to customize and get the formatting right for the symbol of your choice:
https://youtu.be/EsQjZ7tFfr0

So the STL files for a generic ring are included on this page, but you should look at the instructional video I made for Rose’s Rebel Alliance iris ring on how to print and assemble it:
https://youtu.be/tTRXPE5q1eA

Please note that the best way to show your appreciation and keep up to date on my latest 3D printing projects is to head over to my YouTube channel and subscribe!
https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCeQR9E-MPwBqEpuaIJiE4CQ

The only uncommon material needed for this build is M1 x 6mm cheese head screws. I listed my source under in the .pdf (or .xlsx) BOM under “Thing Files”, but hopefully someone can find a better source.

STL quantities to print:
Iris Blade, Hidden Symbol Iris Ring {QTY 6x}
Symbol Insert, Hidden Symbol Iris Ring {QTY 1x}
Base, Hidden Symbol Iris Ring, XXmm ID {QTY 1x} [see below for different sizes]
Cap, Hidden Symbol Iris Ring {QTY 1x}
Slotted Disc, Hidden Symbol Iris Ring {QTY 1x}

For the Ring Base there are various sizes, to fit different finger sizes:
Base, Hidden Symbol Iris Ring, 13mm ID
Base, Hidden Symbol Iris Ring, 15mm ID
Base, Hidden Symbol Iris Ring, 17mm ID
Base, Hidden Symbol Iris Ring, 19mm ID
Base, Hidden Symbol Iris Ring, 21.6mm ID
Base, Hidden Symbol Iris Ring, 23mm ID
Base, Hidden Symbol Iris Ring, 25mm ID

The "XXmm ID" refers to the inner diameter of the ring portion being XXmm in diameter. This should allow you to pick the right size Ring Base for your needs.

Coming a bit late... x)

description.text:
Water seal for shower door in several sizes.

This water seal for a shower door is best printed in TPE material.
In TPE it is flexible enough to follow the curve of the shower door.
It can of course also be printed in PLA, PETG, ABS, but TPE works probably best.

The model shown in the pictures was printed in red TPE material because of the curved door. TPE is more than heat resistant enough to withstand hot water and is chemically resistant against most cleaning agents.
In TPE no adhesive tapes is necessary, the model with fit by friction only.

Model was designed in OpenSCAD.

Creatbot DE

Notes:

If the door seal needs to follow a curve, print with 20% infill to allow for enough flexibility.

title: Stand for Anker QI wireless charger

description.text:
The Anker wireless charge charging pad is Amazon's best seller/Amazon choice QI charger coil for the latest iPhones (8,8+,X) and top Samsung smartphones (link bellow). It is a great and affordable charging pad, but like all "lay-flat pads" it is prone to smartphone positioning errors. This "thing" aims at mitigating this issue: not only it allows charging the smartphone at a tilted angle (60º) but it will always place the device within the reach of the charging coil.

Main features are:

  • Standup charging at 60º
  • Snap-fit: easy assembly and disassembly (portable)
  • Doubles as a portable regular stand
  • Portrait or landscape viewing
  • Prevent smartphone placement errors
  • Pad positioning takes into account several different smartphone models/sizes
  • Prints without supports/rafts (PLA - with ABS you mileage may vary)
  • Looks nice in black or in grey (or any choice of color)

Charging pad easily slides into slot and stays in place due to back pressure.

Link to charger pad: https://www.amazon.com/Anker-Wireless-Charging-Provides-Fast-Charging/dp/B01KJL4XNY

Anycubic I3 Mega

author: Tori68

description.text:
The groove height on groove mount barrels can vary, and sometimes it's hard to make a 3D printed yoke. Then there's E3D, whose version is inexcusably larger than anyone else's.  
This template allows for easy custom thicknesses of shims for a MendelMax 2's standard MaxStruder extruder. The stock design of the top holder depends on building the part just right.

I used different thicknesses of plastic shim stock, and cut them with an engraving laser. Printing out as a template to cut shim stock with a hobby knife might work well too.  
Insert a shim or stack of shims that is thick enough to be reasonably firm on the barrel's groove mount, but not firmly enough to distort the shim stock material or the barrel.  
Two of the files are in inches. I think one might be in millimeters, I forget which one.

title: Black Hole Board Game (Travel Edition)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is my Travel Edition for the Pig Hole / Big Hole / Black Hole board game.
All Items as single files or one file as print all at once. The dice should snap into the hole to close the hole.
I would love to see some makes!

The rules

2 players = 20 coins / each
4 players = 15 coins / each
6 players = 10 coins / each

At first you will roll the dice and see who has the highest number, this person will start.
Round 1: Everybody rolls the dice 1 time and place a coin on the field(s) which he/she diced
Round 2 : Everybody rolls the dice 2 times and place a coin on the field(s) which he/she diced.
Round 3: From here everybody decides by themselves how often he/she rolls the dice.

Attention: If somebody dice a 6, he/she can place the coin in the center hole.
If a field is full of coins the "dicer" has to take all coins from the number field and the next one is in charge.

The winner is the person who has first no coins.
(Sorry for the english, I hope you understand it)

Print Settings

Infill: 15% (100% with the dice and the coins)

Layer: 0,2mm

Supports: no

Rafts: no (maybe with the coins)

Nozzle: 200°C (PLA Setting)

Bed: 60°C (PLA Setting)

Here is the game on amazon made of wood in big:
http://amzn.to/2mx3Hi1

I always use the following tape on my CR-10:
http://amzn.to/2zXjJGu
This stuff is really great, no extra glue needed, 100% sticky to the printed parts, which come off really easily, even without destroying the tape.

Have fun!

(Amazon Affiliate Links / Tip enabled)

title: Garmin eTrex Aero Mount 31.8mm

description.text:
English:

[Not my native language. Hope you understand me. :) ]
I created a Garmin aeromount for my road bike, because my original one did not fit to the diameter of my handlebar (my handlebar is 31.8mm diameter).
I also like that the Garmin is in the middle of my handlebar. :)

If you don´t have it, you also need to print the Clip mount Adapter for the Garmin itself.
I found one on thingi, made by enif: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:167082
You can try it. I did not tested it, I have an original one.

In comparison to the original mount, my mount is really tight. The original one has a really loose connection. There is no tottering now!

Things you also need:
2x DIN912 M5x(25-35mm) OR 2x DIN933 M5x(25-35)
2x DIN934 M5

Außerdem finde ich es gut, dass das Garmin nun in der Mitte vom Lenker ist. :)

Wenn du es noch nicht hast, brauchst du auch den Clip Adapter für das Garmin selber.

title: GoPro quadcopter mount (custom design for Zeus 210 frame)

description.text:
After assembling the quadcopter the other day I was thinking of a way to hold the GoPro and thought that it might be useful to be able to mount it under the battery.

I started with some sketches and than after few measurements and struggles it was time to use Fusion 360
After few hours, modeling in Fusion came to sweet end.

Have fun with my design, hope to see some makes of this one ;)

Please don't sell this on or take my pictures without asking.

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

i3 MK2S

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.1/0.15

Infill:

50%

Notes:

At first I printed holder in natural PLA but It was not strong enough (for me), that's why I used ABS for second try which came out quite nice.
I printed all parts with brim and build plate support. At some height (13.10 mm) I added "color change" just to pause print and insert 4 M5 stainless nuts. Second stop was at height 14mm with purpose to insert some Foam Board support. I choose this way just to avoid ugly leftovers made by support material (you can see in pictures).

author: Y123

description.text:
There are plenty of 18650 battery dispensers here on thingiverse but, surprisingly, none of the existing suited my needs. What I needed was a dispenser for eight batteries, printable without supports with the lower "plate" that holds two batteries (as I'm using batteries always in pair in my mods). Also, I wanted it to have a finger cutout and a sufficient distance from the table where it stands but at the same time I didn't want it to be chunky nor to have to print some sort of spacers.

So, the bottom is 4mm while the rest of the walls are 2.5mm which, I believe is sturdy enough and doesn't bend at at all if printed with PLA.

Of course, this is by no means my original design but rather my rendition of the 18650 battery dispenser. If anyone thinks this is a rip-off or that I should give credit to someone, please let me know and I'll do it. At this point, it seemed to me a bit pointless to paste links to each and every dispenser available here and they all, in a way, influenced me to make this one.

author: m1n1m

description.text: bee ring
print two playground phones and connect with a rubber tube.

One of the shortcomings of the Prusa Mendel design is that, while the mechanical print mechanism is brilliant, it doesn't really have any provision for the associated electronics.  I have seen Mendels where the driver boards are just flopping around on the table next to the printer; I've also seen clamps and other things to affix the RAMPS and Arduino boards in hard-to-see positions on the side of the frame, etc.  None of this is too satisfactory.
I wanted something that worked better, so I augmented the normal frame vertex part for the printer with a rearward-facing projection that can be used as a shelf support.  This lets you put a wooden (e.g.) shelf up high and to the rear of the printer, and attach your electronics to that as needed.  This arrangement makes the entire printer into a solid one-piece unit that can be lifted and moved without problems, and also puts the electronics up high where you can see them easily and make intricate connections without hurting yourself.  It's also a nice "centralized" location, so the wire runs from the motors, switches, and heaters are short.

(1) Print two of the "extended" frame vertex parts from this page.  ABS is probably best since these parts will not only form the new top of your printer's frame, but will also mount and hold your electronics shelf.  Drill the holes that will take the threaded rod to 8.5mm.  Drill the shelf mounting holes to 4mm.
(2) Replace the two existing top vertices on your printer with the new parts.  The printer should be just like before, with the addition of a couple of arms sticking out towards the rear of the printer.
(3) Make a shelf that spans the arms and is big enough to hold you electronics and connectors.  I used 1/2" MDF, but anything would work.  The dimensions are not critical.  Mount the shelf using 4mm bolts and nuts to fit.  Note that the underside of the support has hexagonal openings that will capture the nuts and hold them in place.
(4) Mount your electronics and anything else as needed on the top surface of the shelf.

I remixed my cable slitter.
I added a depth adjustment screw, a blade cover, and a perpendicular slot.
It works a lot better now.

Let me know if it works for you.
Or not...

Here's a short video
https://youtu.be/3TNGuIz2kXw

I have printed this in
PLA 220 nozzle, 60 bed, 0.2 layer, 30% infill
ABS 225 nozzle, 100 bed, 0.2 layer, 50% infill
PETG 235 nozzle, 70 bed, 0.2 layer, 25% infill

I had a problem with the hinge on top of the bottom piece when I printed it in ABS. So I added a patch hinge. If this happens to you, then sand the area smooth and glue on a new hinge so all is not wasted. You can use ABS slurry, super glue, or plumber ABS cement. Super strong stuff.

The single edge razor blade fits a little better in it's holder now. A little bit looser. Mine will float around about 1 mm or so. You still need to clean up this area post print. There is a tiny slot that gets fused back together (on my printers anyway) and it should be cut apart with a razor blade. It is located on the opposite side of the screw, in the front, 5mm up from the base. It makes a locking tab for the blade. You can see it in Thingiview.

I used a 3mm bolt for the hinge and it's a little sloppy. I think an 8-32 fits better.

description.text: My test print on this didn't turn out as pretty as I would have liked, but it worked on a functional level, so I decided to post the model anyway. I think getting a really clean print of this is a matter of fine tuning speed and retraction settings. The cord hanging passageways are open at the bottom of the bowl to facilitate lacing, but that also means that whatever cord you use will be exposed to moisture, so choose something rot resistant. The overall diameter of the model is 137mm because that's a size that would fit on the buildplate of my Ender2 with some brim. No other reason. Scale as you see fit.

print_settings.Notes:: I put in Simplify3D and arranged it so that the bottom surface touched the plate putting inline vertically the majority of the part with support needed for the underside of the foot.  The infield was fast honeycomb.  The advanced settings were to allow single extruder walls and fills.

description.text:
Noob project that I designed from scratch and printed on the Monoprice Maker Select Plus printer using Fusion 360 and Simplify3d. I have the coordinates set kind of awkwardly in the Fusion model and haven’t figured out how to rotate the model or the origin to a more natural position.

This part took about 6-7 hours to print with 0.3 layer hight, 0.93 extrusion multiplier, fast honeycomb, temperature at 207, 3600 mm/min. Allow single extrusion fills, allow single extrusion walls. Generate support on. 6 solid top and bottom layers. 4 solid wall layers.

I've shared the Fusion 360 design if others want to add on to it. I may add additional supports and inclose it fully, but this seems to work fairly well and is very sturdy for a stand. Touchscreen slides in and out easily so you can still tinker with things without unscrewing anything.

Printer:

Monoprice Maker Select Plus

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.3

Infill:

25% Fast Honeycomb

Notes:

Skirt with 3 layers and 6 outlines 2-mm from part. I always seem to have issues with the start of print getting a good layer down and its easier to get the skirt off the bed if there are multiple layers.

Extruder multiplier was 0.93 on this one, but I may knock it back to 0.92 for the 0.3 layer size next time. Not bad quality, but it might be a tad high. 6 layers Top/Bottom and 4 layers wide because I'm tired of having little gaps on the external layers. This looked great.

Temperature is at 207 C for the white Monoprice $20 filament. I think some other filaments I have print better at lower temperature, but this one was having trouble.

I put in Simplify3D and arranged it so that the bottom surface touched the plate putting inline vertically the majority of the part with support needed for the underside of the foot. The infield was fast honeycomb. The advanced settings were to allow single extruder walls and fills.

Fusion 360

I started off with a sketch of the dimensions for the backside of the touchscreen so I could extrude the appropriate configuration. I didn't do a good job of choosing the original coordinate system so its a bit awkward to rotate the model. I'm not sure yet how to fix that.

The shared Fusion 360 model is here is one would like to play with it.
https://gallery.autodesk.com/fusion360/projects/raspberry-pi-7-touchscreen-stand

I also included the Simplify3d stl object and the Fusion 360 stl object.

comments.text: I think I may need to extend the height just a bit to make the USB power connection a little less constrained, but it works.  I may try to print a camera adaptor that clips to the top of the screen to hold the PICam.

author: cquest

print_settings.Infill:: 20% should be fine for the base, the trays don't matter.

description.text: Have you still got lots of cassette tapes you can't or won't part with, then you may need a rack. I'm too stubborn to buy one so I thought I'd make one. Enjoy!

Printer:

My home made I2 clone.

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.4mm or better.

Infill:

20% should be fine for the base, the trays don't matter.

Notes:

1) When printing the trays, be careful not to overstuff the walls or it'll look rough.
2) When printing the base, you could use a 0.5mm nozzle for speed but it'll start looking ugly as it's got a sloping top section. Also, you probably should use the forthcoming modifier tool with slic3r or suchlike to reinforce the holes in the base.
3) Take care centering the base on the printbed unless you have a very large printer as it uses up almost all of it.
4) After printing, cut and thread two equal lengths of steel to hold the whole stack together. Put M6 nuts on the bottom with a little medium strength loctite and capnuts on top with low strength loctite 222e.
You may want to run a drill 6mm drill through the holes to make sure they're clear, then you should gently remove any lumps and bumps from the mating faces on the trays.

Design Approach

Firstly, I had a little idea or three. Then I picked out a favourite based on aesthetics and ease of printing.

I took measurements of a few sample cassette cases and drew a tray to fit it. After printing and testing the tray, I designed the base whilst printing a few more trays. I'm still waiting for the base to print but I noticed that the angle which makes it sit nicest with four or five trays is 12 degrees, your mileage may vary depending on how high you go but I don't think this tower wants to go much higher and left it at that.

A tool was created to cut the screw holes in the base and the holes subsequently plugged with a thin layer to aid in printing. Other essentials were drawn and used to represent the final assembly so that I could see that everything fits together properly.

In conclusion, I could have spent more time making the model more parametric, neater, easier to adjust etc but I'm still quite pleased with the way it came out.

title: AM8 X Axis Holders for E3D Anti Backlash Nut

description.text:
X axis holders, designed with AM8 in mind, and compatible with E3D anti backlash nuts.

Features:

  • Designed for AM8 and to be compatible with the official E3D Anti-backlash nuts.
  • Smooth rods sit a bit deeper in than with the original Anet A8 holders. Keep this in mind when using an X tensioner, as you will need longer screws.
  • Compatible with the following X tensioner: ANET A8 X- axis belt Tensioner (x- Achsen Riemenspanner) M4, but you will probably need longer screws.
  • X endstop similar to the original Anet A8.
  • I suggest using LM8LUU type linear bearings to decrease Z wobble.
  • Installation more/less identical to the original, but with easier smooth rod insertion, provided that your printer is within good tolerances.

As usual, I am including the Blender source file in case you want to edit it.

Nightmare Rarity

comments.text: Did you notice big improvements from the backlash nuts? I'm planing to upgrade but I'm not shure if they would improve my prints that much...
comments.author: Redflame5

comments.text: They are relevant only if you are using Z-hop and auto leveling, as both of these features cause a lot of upwards and downwards movement. In situations like these, you want to minimize the baklash as much as possible. You can easily check if you have any backlash by locking your Z motors and trying to move the whole X assembly up-down by hand. If there is even a tiny amount of movement it can do, then you probably need the anti baklash nuts.

author: Hiluxman

description.text:
I have several 3D printers and I needed some way of easily transferring filament from one spool to another so that two (or more) printers could be printing from the same spool of filament. I use Hatchbox brand filament and their hub design makes this pretty easy.

I used a 1/4x20 threaded rod, nuts and washers to make the drive shaft and a wing nut to secure the empty spool to the shaft. Any drill can be used that can handle a 1/4 inch drill. I used a bench vise to hold a standard spool holder for the full spool. It works well and is quick to transfer the filament. It also takes up very little room to store when not in use.

Use at least 50% infill and 2mm shell to print.

Enjoy!

title: Tablet Stand / Tripod (works with Samsung Tab A 8.0 2017)

description.text:
A tripod holder and stand for my son's Samsung Tab A 8.0 (2017). It uses standard #2 pencils ;), cut to the same length, as legs. This fits around the rubber/plastic case for the tablet. It is currently holding nice and tightly due to the press fit of the dovetail joint.

I used the Tablet Tripod Mount by lynce9956 as inspiration for my design. My son liked his design but wanted a few things different so we redesigned it from scratch. If you print yours at a finer resolution than I used, 0.32 mm layer height, the dovetail joint might fit a bit loser. My suggestion would be to add an elastic band in the dovetail area such as what was done by lynce9956. They used two eye screws and a rubber band to create tension to hold it closed.

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

i3 MK2S

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.32

Notes:

I printed this in a really rough layer height as my son was being impatient and just wanted this stand to use his tablet as a camera. The large layer lines meant the fit was just slightly tight, but this worked well as I didn't have to add any springs or elastics to tension it around the tablet. I printed this laying on it's side so that the layers would help increase the strength. (i.e. the layer are parallel to the stress).

Designed in Fusion 360

Fairly simple design. My son told me what he wanted and I translated that to a printable object.

comments.text:
Hi Pierre
I got board with following the last conversation, the tree was getting long..
I finally got around to assembling the machine. Have to work Mon to Fri, so today was a good day to do it.
The assembly drove me nuts for a while, Until I realized 2 of the 4 Zaxis pipe couplers are inverted.
Fixed that and it assembled beautifully.
The belt brackets had to be mirrored for 2 of the 4.
The offset hole in these brackets goes thru the tube, did you do this on purpose? It would constrain the tube length, and would also mean drilling thru the tube.
I have not fitted the wire chain parts yet, I do not know what wire chain I can get, and am also considering putting them over the top keeping the "throat" of the machine clear. I will figure this out when I start to physically assemble I think.
I have at this stage no idea what my build size is. The aim is x=1250, Y=1250 and Z=400. Our STD sheet size here is 2500x1250, so I am allowing for half a sheet to fit. The z height is to allow for 3d printing.
If you know what the dimensions should be, it would save me a bit of time working it out.

I will probably not use the solidworks assembly, as it will lose its parametrics when I open it in Inventor. If I have all the sld parts I can quickly assemble them in a new assembly. From what I have seen, you still use ansi fasteners, while they will be close to metric, they may not be exact. I may have to make allowance for this. I also noticed that you have used captive nuts, I will have to make allowances for this as well, depending on what nuts I can get off the shelf here. Unlike the U.S. we are limited to what we can get. Importing from the U.S. is not really an option, as the shipping kills me ie. 10cents for a nut 10 dollars to ship. Also our customs have "lost it" when individuals try to bring stuff into the country.
I seriously considered making the MPCNC, as there is a guy in the U.S. who is selling all the required hardware in a bundle, from memory 286 usd for hardware, and 165 usd for printed parts (excludes tubing) https://vicious1-com.myshopify.com/collections/parts/products/mostly-printed-cnc-parts-bundle. These prices are roughly half of what it would cost me here. He offers to ship free to the U.S., as I have someone in the us who would already ships components to SA, I could conceivably have the parts shipped to this guy, and then added to his next shipment out here, it would fall under the same regulations as the parts he already ships, so customs should not be an issue. I am telling you this, because if I decide (mostly decided already) I will probably buy the hardware here if it conforms to your specs, and ship it all in one bundle.

comments.author: RobinPis

comments.text:
Hi Pierre
I appreciate your comments. I assume you have more experience at this than I do. (none)
My intention was to make the parts with PLA (esun pla+) This would serve for the prototype, I could adjust the material on any parts that show signs of wear or deformation.
1) 3d printing - seeing as how I expect the machine to be printing mostly if not exclusively ABS, I have found that a constant temperature inside the enclosure of 45 to 48 degc gives me the best result with ABS. That's one reason for the enclosure. It does not need to be airtight.
2) Routing - No real temp constraints, but certainly messy, be it wood, plastic or ali, so the enclosure would contain this to a large degree.
3) Laser cutting - From your comment I presume you are concerned with temp affecting the plastic parts. From what I know, the heat generated by the laser is very localized to where the beam makes contact to the material. (Not a radiant heat source) A constant airflow (extraction fan on the enclosure) would dissipate the heat generated long before it reached the plastic parts. The extraction would be required to disperse any gasses generated by the material being cut, so is an integral component anyway.
4) Plasma would have the same conditions as laser, granted the heat generated would be substantially higher. This addition would have other considerations, one that comes to mind is, the all the other processes could be carried out on a wooden base, the plasma could not.

comments.text: Please re-download zip files
comments.author: RobinPis

comments.text:
I downloaded files.
I will not start the project though until I can create an assembly.
After making this rough model, I see the need of a heat shield.
The plasma gun would need a steel bracket, with a heat break before attaching to the plastic parts.
The front doors on the enclosure would only be fitted when in 3d print mode, allowing extraction airflow in the other modes.
comments.author: crunchysann

comments.text: Wow I like that enclosure and plasma mount position. I was think of a more compact enclosure but your design is a lot simpler to make. Keep us up to date on your progress :) good luck.
comments.author: RobinPis

comments.text:
Hi Pierre
I have made a similar enclosure for my 3d printer, It worked very well. Where I bought the kit wanted 290usd for an enclosure, which I thought was excessive. I had 1/2 sheet of acrylic lying around, as well as quite a few glass panes from an old cottage window frame, so decided to make my own. All I had to buy was 2 6mtr lengths of 19x19 ali tube, which the supplier cut to size for me, They have the correct tools to cut neatly, cost 22usd.
As I was new to 3d printing, I had quite a few issues getting the printer to work properly, and I was always taking the machine apart and reassembling it (constant nozzle jams, which I have solved). Because of this I wanted easy access to the printer, so I made all the panels slide out. In hindsight this was not necessary, and if I did it again I would use fixed panels. The entire box is independent of the printer so If I need to get at anything, just unplug the control box and lift the box off, it weighs literally nothing.
I only close the doors when printing ABS, or Nylon (which I have yet to master) to maintain a constant temp in the enclosure. I have 2 cleats on the front top door, through which I have 2 M5x50 machine screws, which allows me to leave the door slightly open to regulate the temp. I can get a more or less constant temp of 45 to 48 deg in the box. Without this regulator the internal temp can climb to 55 deg on prints longer than 2 hrs or so. As the electronics are still inside the box this worries me a bit.
From the pictures you will see that the glass all have a frame around them, these friction fit to the glass, and the frames were printed with the hinges. I saw this done on a youtube somewhere and was keen to try it, IT WORKED.
Another consideration was printing Nylon, which is extremely hydroscopic, so I made the box high enough to allow me to put the nylon filament inside the box, (ABS and PLA sit on top, easier access) in the hopes that the higher temp would repel any moisture in the air. I have not printed nylon since the box completion.

title: Flip Lock Tripod Model FL Locking Lever

description.text:
My Flip Lock tripod was damaged in airline transport some years ago. The consumer Flip Lock model FL is light, very easy to use and fast to setup. I resorted to a pair of little vice grips to adjust the leg with the broken lever.

Enter my brand new Zonestar P802QR2 3d printer. I decided to learn the complete 3d process by fabricating a replacement lever for my tripod. The part has simple geometry, it is small and it is useful, so an ideal first time project.

Printer:

P802QR2

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

20%

Notes:

The CuraEngine Slicer defaults result in a very flexible lever. Qurntum 3D PLA filament was used.
Leave the remaining threads on the object, just to show you made it yourself!

Simple 3 part FreeCAD model

This was an ideal part to learn the FreeCAD basics. The hardest part was learning how to drill a pocket in the object.

Beginners' Tip: Select the surface you wish to drill into before creating the pocket!

Once the outline of the lever is sketched and extruded to 10mm height, drill a 5mm pocket into the barrel 8mm deep. Save as an STL and slice.

The hygrometer has a couple of magnets mounted on its back and this design couples those magnets with 2 more that are secure inside the mounting bracket.

This is a 180° wrist mod for the Inmoov Robot. Thanks to Gael Langevin for such a great project.

The wrist can have full movement without the fingers moving. The hand shown is made from ninjaflex.

The servo will have to be hacked to remove the potentiometer, in the same manner as some of the other servos in the robot. Don't forget to remove the pin on the potentiometer gear inside the servo.
The servo has to be attached with 3 screws, not 4 as the 4th will interfere with the potentiometer. It's self explanatory when installing the servo.

I am using the EZ-Robot HDD digital servo, strong and quiet. http://www.ez-robot.com/Shop/AccessoriesDetails.aspx?prevCat=9&productNumber=7

description.text:
This is a remix from Midlands3D "FPV Pod for board camera & Fatshark vtx" (thank you Midlands!)
This remix has been designed to fit between the top rails of the FT mini arrow fuselage designed by HaikuFPV (thanks HaikuFPV!)
I found that I couldn't fit my fpv gear in the fuselage if the battery was in there, so I designed a pod/sled that would be universally compatible with any standard board cam and vtx of your choice.
I made the sled less wide so it will fit between the rails of the front fuselage. The front of the pod is wider so I made cut-outs to fit on top of the rails.
Also added tie-down anchors for zip ties or rubber bands so you'll be able to secure this on almost any plane/vehicle.
Zip ties are used for the original design, so if you wanted to use small screws, you'll need to tinker the diameter of the cam mounting holes a bit smaller.

author: porlock

description.text:
Made a simple break-card to store your crypto-wallet 12/24 word seed. Design is based on the "launch code verification break cards" supposedly used in nuclear launch bunkers. Designed to fit with the empty spreadsheet card that comes with the Ledger Nano S hardware wallet.

Instructions:
Wrap the card you're planning to put inside in aluminum foil. This will prevent anyone from using a light source to look through it. It will also make it extremely hard to obtain the inside information using a radiation source or other material-penetrating techniques.
Use a brim on the print to make it stand up, and print it until there is a couple of layers left before it seals (around layer 600 using 200µm print layers). Then pause the print, insert the card, and then let the print finish.

This print will of course not inhibit anyone from stealing the card itself, so it should be placed somewhere safe and hidden. What it will do, is to a better degree ensure you that no one has seen the seed, and if they have seen it, you will know it has been tampered with, and should be disposed of.

Printer:

HyperCube

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

200µm

Infill:

95

title: Mini NES Pi 3 Case (with support pieces removed)

description.text:
This is a reboot of the ini NES Pi 3 Case (Customizable) by LKM.

The problem I had with his build is the support pieces for elevated lines were built into the design. I removed these support pieces in order to let the software (Cura for me) put in the support. I also had trouble with the bottom part of the build. There is an image that indicates the parts of the bottom that I had to trim with a knife. Hopefully, V2 will solve this for you. My build is the plain body style with no text.

Bottom V2 is not tested. Please comment if V2 works for you.

Summary from the original thing:

This Raspberry Pi 3 NES case...

Is visually as close as possible to a real NES

  • Fits a Raspberry Pi 3
  • Has plenty of space in the case for additional parts
  • Is made in OpenSCAD and customizable
  • Is easily assembled and disassembled without screws (exception: the Pi itself is screwed to the bottom section of the case)
  • Provides simple access to all ports
  • Can be printed and assembled very easily (arguably, this one is a slight miss :-)
  • Please watch this video showing tips for printing, and how to assemble the pieces:

comments.text: Hi! Thanks for your feedback. From my side it was enough to tighten the screw firmly by holding the rotary wheel, like I described in the assembly instructions. If that's not working for you and you don't plan to disassemble it, you can add a little bit of glue for sure. And yes, depending on printer accuracy, print settings, it may be needed to handle the sliding surfaces with a file. I think, that's better than if they would be too loose.

This is a case for the DBR04 firing system. It's used to protect the DBR04 from rain and sparks.
V1 is designed for placing three DBR04 in one suitcase while V2 is modified in size and shape to allow storing six of the systems in one suitcase. Moreover the top part of V2 snaps into place when put on the bottom part.

print_settings.Printer:: Wanhao Duplicator i3 V2

title: Wanhao duplicator i3 v2, Z-brace with multiple configuration options.

description.text:
Z-braces for Wanhao duplicator i3 v2.
These braces may not be as rigid as some other designs but it has some advantages.
It´s still like day and night compared to a non braced frame and I can print at twice the speed with even better results than before.
Print all parts with 100% infill.

Pros:

  1. Looks.
  2. Can be directed to front or rear.
  3. Uses very little material to print.
  4. Easy to adjust, no tools needed after initial assembly.
  5. Will not interfere with your workspace around the build plate.
  6. Make your printer totally square.
  7. Print a second set and mount to lower part of the tower or between the extrusions for even more adjustment possibilities.
  8. Always the correct angle. Will not initiate unwanted bending forces.
  9. No aluminium? Use a rigid board (min 450x450 mm) like MDF. Place your printer on top and fasten with wood screws.
  10. Looks

Cons:

  1. Not as rigid as some other designs. (I think)
  2. Some parts need support when printed. (Bad design, sorry)
  3. Makes your friends jealous for having such a fancy printer.

Print 2 pcs of each:
Top_plate.stl (Mirror one pc)
Bottom_plate.stl (Mirror one pc, need support)
Top_joint_v2.stl (Need support)
Bottom_joint_v3.stl (Need support)
Locknut.stl (need support)
Adjust_nut_15_slot.stl
DT_nut_18.stl (You may need to redesign depending on what type of profile you use)

Print 4 pcs of each
Angle.stl
DT_nut_12.stl (You may need to redesign depending on what type of profile you use)

Hardware:
M4x16 hex flat-head cap screw, 2 pcs
M4x20 hex flat-head cap screw, 2 pcs
M3x8 hex socket cap screw, 28 pcs
M6 threaded rod 1m (2 pcs cut in length)
6mm id washer, 4 pcs
M4 nylon lock nut, 2 pcs
M4 nut, 2 pcs
M6 nut, 8 pcs
Aluminium extruded profile, L= 500 mm, 2 pcs
(I used a profile with 8 mm gap)

title: snowflake that grows
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This thing was made with BlocksCAD
Before I start this thing, I watched several videos of how real snowflakes grow. The idea to make a snowflake grows by itself. Change the value of p from 15 to 75 and you will see how the snowflake grows. And if you print out all the snowflakes in steps of 10, setting the value a = 1 (which would have a hole appeared in the center) and collect snowflakes on a string from bigger to smaller, putting between them slices of a cocktail tube 5-10 mm in length, then you get a Christmas tree)))
I will explain about the variables used in this thing:
set a:
-If you need a hole in the center of the snowflake, set "1"
-If on one of the hands, to hang the snowflake, set "2"
-If the hole is unnecessary "3" or more.
set m: - the module on which the scale depends, the default size is 15
set t: - 1/2 thickness of snowflake, default 2mm
set s: - number of hands, default 6
set f: - number of faces, default 6
set r: - radius of a snowflake. changes in growth occur from 15 to 75mm.

Edit this project at BlocksCAD: https://www.blockscad3d.com/editor?from=71810
Or, download the .xml file and load it at: https://www.blockscad3d.com/editor

author: Vasa

print_settings.Notes:: You have to activate the "spiral vase" mode of your slicing software.

description.text:
This bottom vase is the result of a geometric experiment in BricsCAD. The construction consists of three intersecting circles, like a Venn diagram. The top and bottom areas are the common intersections of the three circles. The middle part widens to the combined area of the circles. Three splines connect the three defining levels organically.

Diese Vase ist das Ergebnis eines Geometrieexperiments in BricsCAD. Die Konstruktion besteht aus drei überlappenden Kreisen, wie bei einem Mengendiagramm. Boden und Öffnung werden durch die gemeinsame Schnittmenge gebildet, der mittlere Teil dehnt sich zur Vereinigungsmenge aus. Drei Splines verbinden die drei Ebenen auf biologisch wirkende Weise.

author: bohne

description.text: Proyecto destinado a talleres o cursos de electrónica y robótica educativa.

Printer:

i3BOXed

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No
NGSS
Este proyecto forma parte de los ejercicios que se realizan en cursos de Arduino y cursos de programación con Bitbloq.

Objetivo El objetivo de este proyecto es afianzar el manejo de los miniservos conociendo las diversas recomendaciones para alargar la vida de estos actuadores. Aprender a manejar los lásers y sobretodo conocer y aplicar las medidas de seguridad en el manejo de este tipo de LED. Ejercicios 1 Iniciamos aquí una serie de ejercicios con idea de construir una torreta con dos ajes de giro. La torreta dispondrá de un joystick que controlará ambos ejes de giro. En este primer ejercicio nos limitaremos a ajustar los mini-servos. En primer lugar debes hacer oscilar el miniservo inferior entre 5º (encendiendo el LED) y 165º (apagando el LED). Todo ello cada 2 segundos (2000 ms). En segundo lugar debes hacer oscilar el miniservo superior entre 5º (encendiendo el LED) y 150º (apagando el LED). Todo ello cada 2 segundos (2000 ms). IMPORTANTE: No olvides dejar una pausa de 30ms (aprox) después de cada movimiento del miniservo. Esta mínima pausa sirve para proteger la integridad del motor. RECOMENDACIÓN: Es siempre recomendable no llevar el miniservo ni a su mínimo (0º) ni a su máximo (180º). De este modo lograremos aumentar la vida del motor. Ejercicio 2 Proseguimos con la programación de nuestra Torreta de Combate y, en esta ocasión, vamos a incorporar el Joystick. Vamos a programar los dos potenciómetros del Joystick. El miniservo inferior debe oscilar entre 5º y 165º para el eje X. El miniservo superior debe oscilar entre 150º y 5º para el eje Y. Ejercicio 3 ATENCIÓN: Este ejercicio incluye un Diodo Láser. Esto no es un juguete. Debes realizar este ejercicio con la ayuda y vigilancia de un adulto. Poco a poco proseguimos la programación de nuestra torreta de combate. Es el momento de presentar el LED láser. Bitbloq no incorpora, como tal, el LED láser. Lo que haremos será sustituirlo por un LED normal y corriente ya que, a todos los efectos, funciona exactamente igual a un láser. El láser permanecerá encendido en todo momento y lo podremos dirigir desplazando la torreta con el joystick. Practica en afinar la puntería y ... recuerda ... un láser no es un juguete; ¡cuidado con los ojos! Ejercicio 4 ATENCIÓN: Este ejercicio incluye un Diodo Láser. Esto no es un juguete. Debes realizar este ejercicio con la ayuda y vigilancia de un adulto. En esta nueva entrega de nuestra torreta de combate vamos a estudiar cómo manejar el pulsador del joystick. Ejercicio 5 ATENCIÓN: Este ejercicio incluye un Diodo Láser. Esto no es un juguete. Debes realizar este ejercicio con la ayuda y vigilancia de un adulto. Casi hemos concluido la programación de nuestra Torreta de Combate. Vamos a añadir un sensor de luz que servirá para registrar los impactos láser de otras torretas. Ejercicio 6 ATENCIÓN: Este ejercicio incluye un Diodo Láser. Esto no es un juguete. Debes realizar este ejercicio con la ayuda y vigilancia de un adulto. Terminamos esta serie de ejercicios incorporando un potenciómetro a nuestra torreta de combate láser. ¿Para qué un potenciómetro? Utilizaremos esta resistencia variable para calibrar la sensibilidad del sensor de luz. Recordemos que el sensor de luz es el que detecta los impactos láser de otras torretas. Siendo que las condiciones de luz no siembre van a ser iguales, es conveniente calibrar el sensor de luz de modo que no salte con la luz ambiente sino únicamente cuando le incida una luz superior como la de un láser disparado por otra torreta. Este proceso de calibrado solamente lo tendremos que llevar a cabo una vez al inicio de la sesión de juego con nuestra torreta. Es por eso que el código necesario lo colocaremos en la zona de Instrucciones Iniciales o Setup. Cuando consideremos que hemos calibrado el sensor de luz, solamente tendremos que pulsar el botón del Joystick para dar paso a las instrucciones del Bucle Principal o Loop. UNA REFLEXIÓN Bien pensado, no sería necesario incorporar un potenciómetro para calibrar el sensor de luz. Existen dos razones para ello. La primera es que el Joystick ya incorpora dos potenciómetros. Y la segunda ... podríamos prescindir de todo potenciómetro y realizar el calibrado tan solo mediante software. ¿Te atreves?

I needed some wire number tags and didn't see any here, so I made my own.
1 through 0 on a common brim for easy printing.
The tags are 10mmX20mm, and 1mm tall and the brim is 0.25mm tall.
The numbers are another 1mm tall so including the numbers the overall height is 2mm.
The numbers themselves are 8mmX6mm.

Cut apart post print with scissors.
Here's a quick video:
https://youtu.be/J8okGJIKzTc

I made a second set slightly smaller 10mm X 15mm - everything else is the same, I just trimmed 5mm off the end

I used the straight part from https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1057686, duplicated it 3 times, elongated it a bit so that it fits 4 capsules per row and added 3 holes so that it eats up less material.
It fits nicely on a Pixie, you just need to stick it on there with some double sided tape.

The gcode file is for printing on a Mecreator 2.

description.text:
Tracking with the PS Camera for Playstation VR is improved if the camera is elevated.

The included camera stand can be placed on top of your TV but requires you to be directly in front of the stand, in my living room I sit off to the side when playing PSVR so I needed to find a way to point the camera in the right direction.

Instead of having a freely rotating joint I wanted specific angles (trial and error here, the weight of the cord kept tugging and displacing any freely rotating joint I made), thus you set the angle when placing the camera and no matter the tugging it stays in place.

Besides the angle thing, this also provides some extra height. Because why not.

To use this you'll need the original PS Camera stand and you'll need to print the base as well as EITHER Holder A and Holder B OR Holder A+B

I printed at .1 mm res with 15% infill. Could probably print rougher.

If you print the Holder A and Holder B separate files you won't need any supports, but you will need to glue them together. Holder A + B combines the two and will need support.

The base does not require support.

Step 1: Assembly

If you printed the two separate holder parts (A and B respectively), glue them together.

Step 2: Mounting

Place the PS camera in the included stand, and place the stand in the holder.
Place the base on your TV and set down the holder at your preferred angle

Step 3: ??? Step 4: Profit

description.text: I bought a JavaPress manual coffee grinder awhile ago and I started to have a lot of hand fatigue and sore wrist and finger joints trying to keep the barrel from turning while grinding beans. The stainless steel barrel can be very slippery so I thought, why not make a holder to take the stress out of my morning grind. After some trial and error, I came up with this and so far I'm pretty happy with it.

Printer:

monoprice mini v2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.1

Infill:

100%

Notes:

Print solid to maximize strength. Hex hole is for 1/4-20 jam nut.

I used a 1/4-20 jam nut. Its a tight fit so be careful pressing it in the hex indentation. Use a Popsicle stick between the press and the thumb screw to prevent marring the coffee grinder. It also helps keeps the grinder from slipping. In the base, I put in a circle of foam sheet for the same reason. Cut a 2x2 to 4" and attach to a base (in my case, a square of 1/2" plywood).
Screw the top and bottom with a wood screw as shown. Clamp the base to a surface and grind away. May help to hold the top of the post to steady it while grinding if your clamp is small.

author: GilaRaz

description.text:
I Remixed CheesyTech's original shift knob again. I've been using it for my Mazda 3. My last remix was crushed in hand by the guy at the oil change place, so I decided to make this one a little stronger. Added braces inside, and combined the bottom 2 pieces into 1. But it is still hollow so it can be filled.

I poured in sand and Copperhead BB's to test what worked the best. With just sand, the knob weighed 3.2 oz. With just BB's, I got it up to 5.7 oz. It rattles a bit with just the BB's, which you may like, or might be annoying; personal preference I guess. Then I mixed BB's and sand, laying down a layer of BB's then a layer of sand, alternating until it was full. The mix made it weigh just slightly more, 5.9 oz, and got rid of the rattling. After the holes were filled, I poured some super glue in each to set everything in place.

description.text:
Upgrade your Ender 2 with this fan duct and get better pla-prints!

The Ender 2 3D-Printer performs nicely out of the box already, but it is lacking one thing: A proper part cooling fan. With this upgrade you will be able mount a 5015 radial fan to the hotend, to provide that extra cooling, that will make your pla-prints even better.

To do the Upgrade you will need:

  • 5015 radial fan
  • 4020 silent axial fan (optional)
  • (2x) M4x25 machine screw
  • the screws, that were on the old bracket (don't lose them!)
  • soldering iron
  • some cable
  • a few heatshrinks
  • zipties

This object is a piece of chess of my own desing.
i´m not sure aboat the dimensions of the object so in case you want to print it off i recomend you to costumize to your own messures.
the plan just print
Materials needed Plastic and 3D printer.

print_settings.Notes:: Use Concentric Fill.

description.text:
Additional things needed to build;
1) 2mm foam sheet
2) 3mm diameter neodymium magnets (3mm tall)
3) Multiple levels of sand paper (Dry/Wet)
4) Super Glue, Fabric Glue, Glue you trust
5) Finishing touches (fabric, paint, jewels, etc)

Tried fabric on a practice piece, didn't use anything to keep the fabric from fraying so I didn't like how it turned out but I think it would look good with fabric.

Magnet on the bottom is to attach it to a base which I have not yet created.

I attached Solidworks file for those that want to change it.

Heavily inspired by Jooxoe3i amazing lay flat Easter egg.

Printer:

Prusa MK2/S

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.15mm

Infill:

20%

Notes:

Use Concentric Fill.

1) Sand, Sand, Wet Sand

The more you sand the more it will feel like an egg.

2) Get 2mm sheet foam, cut, and glue

Find some white 2mm foam sheets at your local hobby shop.
Draw out the edge of inside egg.
Cut wide, fit, and cut again.
Glue with super glue or something similar.

3) Sand some more

To get a better fit with the foam, sand the foam down with the egg.

4) Get 3mm Neodymium Magnets

They are 3mm in diameter and 3mm tall.
Place according to the pictures

Might need to mallet them in.

5) Finishing touches

Now paint, cover in fabric, stick things to it, make it your own.

title: Braiding Star For Laces, Headbands & Bracelets
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a braiding for easy doing Laces, Headbands & Bracelets. Simply us 7 Strings (eg wool) and knot them together on one side. Then push the knot through the hole in the star. Clamp the 7 Strings into the guides on the edges and leave one empty. Now use the third string counterclockwise and reallocate to the empty slit.Move on and a thicker string is braided in the middle.

You can buy this stars from wood very cheap on amazon. But i designed it to try out Fusion 360 and learn something for myself with a simpe thing.

Please leave a Like or a comment, thank you!

description.text:
Medieval Sword

This is part of a full set off weapons with the same theme;

  • Medieval Axe => https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2764517
  • Medieval Spear => https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2772754
  • Medieval Flail =>https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2780958

Total length = 1.15 metre (45,27 inch).

Total Print Time (depending on your settings) = ±57 hours.

Components (10);

  • Printed parts (5)
    o Blade-1
    o Blade-2
    o Blade-3
    o Guard
    o Pommel
  • Standard components (5)
    o 4 Wooden dowels 8mm x 35mm
    o PVC pipe diameter 32mm length 240mm

The 4 dowels are used to connect the 3 blade pieces together (you could choose print components instead of using the wooden dowels). The dowels actually worked out great, they made for an excellent connection between the 3 blade pieces.

Pvc pipe will function as grip (you can choose the length of the pvc pipe as you like I went for a length of 240mm).

Printer:

Creality CR-10

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

10%

Notes:

Slicer Cura

All piece where printed with a Brim.

The 3 pieces of the blade (Blade-1,2 and 3) and the pommel where printed without supports.

The guard piece needed some adjusting I had to lower the Overhang angle for support to 30 degrees instead of the default 60 degrees.

Modelling

Modelled in Fusion 360 with mostly basic features like extrudes, revolves, chamfers and rounds.
Skulls where a Brep ( Basic representation) off the beautiful skull model by trailogy and where just placed in the model using the insert Mesh feature.

Engraving is done with the Vivaldi font.

Original skull https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:518109

title: Case for Ramps Full Graphics and Raspberry Pi Zero for Octoprint with ATX Power Supply Control

description.text:
15/01/2018: Added cover option without frame holder

I developed this case to be able to use a Raspberry Pi Zero to run the Octoprint.

My goal was also to control an ATX source with the Octoprint. For this, I used an NPN transistor (general purpose) that is controlled by the GPIO of Raspberry. The transistor switches on / off the PS_ON cable from the ATX source. Anyone using another type of power source can use a relay or an SSR to turn the source (s) on/off.

Raspberry is powered by the 5VSB cable (usually blue) from the ATX source. This cable always has power, even if PS_ON is off.

I did not make a circuit board specific to this circuit because it is very simple.

The reset button is connected to the Ramps reset button. The E-Stop button I solded in the place of Ramps stop push-button. As the buttons used are too tall I drew a small ring to complete the space between the top of the button and the case. This can all be changed in the IGS file that I am making available.

The box design I adapted from this case found in GrabCad: https://grabcad.com/library/lcd-case-for-ramps-1-4-3d-printer-1. Thanks Grzegorz Treter for saving me some time: D

Anyone who wants more information about controlling the source (or using relays) can check this page: https://github.com/foosel/OctoPrint/wiki/Controlling-a-relay-board-from-your-RPi. I used the "PSU Control" plugin of the octoprint to make it work. I've attached a plugin settings screen.

The design of the holder is different from the photo. After printing I realized that the stand should be in front of the cable entry and not behind.

Estabilizador de imagen

Este estabilizador de video esta fabricado con tecnología 3D FDM en la mayoría de sus componentes, usa un sistema de corrección de posición de cámara usado en el mundo de los drones. Este estabilizador funciona con cámaras deportivas como Go-Pro, Eken, H9 Ultra HD 4K , H2 4K Ultra HD, siendo coste del producto final es muy asequible.
Materiales:
Piezas Impresas en 3D (www.thigiverse.com).
3 Puños de bicicleta.
1 Tubo de aluminio de diámetro 16mm x 350 mm.
1 Tubo de aluminio de diámetro 16 mm x 150 mm.
1 Estabilizador de drones. https://www.ebay.es/itm/DJI-Phantom-Brushless-Gimbal-Camera-Mount-C-Motor-Controller-P-Gopro3-FPV-2-AXIS/202112696347?hash=item2f0edb001b:g:d6gAAOSwxixaCgA1

1 Bateria de 12 V 2200Mh. https://www.tomtop.com/es/p-rm8353.html?currency=EUR&Warehouse=CN&aid=gplaescd&mid=10000016480&utm_source=SEM&utm_medium=Google+PLA&utm_campaign=TT_PLA_ES_CD&utm_content=3707&gclid=Cj0KCQiAyZLSBRDpARIsAH66VQK0Dvqx5uduFnO7R3apSsqqgHDFtE8QmR3uGQcGsZ1JIdnoW4YoK-4aAhqiEALw_wcB

28 Tornillos de M3 X20.
28Tuercas de M3.
4 tornillos rosca chapa pequeños.

MONTAJE - (Las fotos están en el orden correcto)

Comenzamos con la barra de aluminio de 350mm acoplando los soportes de los puños y montando el soporte del estabilizador, también acoplamos el tubo de 150 mm. como se muestra en la foto.

Centramos el soporte del estabilizador al centro de la barra de 350 mm.

Y posicionamos los puños en posición perpendicular como en la foto de abajo.

Seguimos con el cajetín de la batería, la pletina metálica del estabilizador que trae de serie y el estabilizador.

Usaremos ocho tornillos de roca chapa pequeños cuatro por debajo uniendo el estabilizador con la caja de batería, y otros cuatro por la parte superior uniendo la caja de batería y la pletina metálica del estabilizador.

Los tornillos de unión suelen venir con el kit del estabilizador .

Para unir el estabilizador y la caja de la batería al cuerpo central del soporte usaremos cuatro tornillos de M8 con sus correspondientes tuercas, aprovechando los orificios que tienes las gomas estabilizadoras que trae el estabilizador.

Finalmente montamos el puño central del estabilizador como se muestra en la fotografiá.

Y finalmente acoplamos el puño y su soporte al conjunto.

remixed_from.title: Parametric pulley - lots of tooth profiles

description.text:
Z Axis sync Belt set for the ever popular D-Bot

If you have 1 z axis which always seems to be a few mm out when you home after a print you need this!

Completely stops Z axis lead screws getting out of sync.

You must unplug 1 motor , weird and strange things will happen if you leave both motors plugged in.

BOM

1 x M6 x 30 Bolt
1 x M6 Nylock Nut
2 x S686Z Bearings ( 6mm ID , 13mm OD, 5mm thickness )
2 x M6 Flat Washers
3 x M6 Split washers (used as spacers to contact the inner race on the bearings )
900 MM GT2 Closed loop belt

Pulleys are designed for 20mm OD motor to lead screw couplers ( droftarts excellent parametric pulleys )

15/01/18 - I have added printable bearing spacers ( untested i used the washers on prototype but have since turned my own out of aluminium )

remixed_from.title: Another Duet WiFi Enclosure with Fan

description.text:
This is a remix of
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1830918
Which was the best Duet box I could find and was one of the very few that put the cooling fan in the right general area (blowing on back of the controller). It also used an 80mm fan of which I had a few handy.

Decided I needed to do a few minor tweaks to get it to more my liking though.

  • I replaced the grill cutout on the cover with some Duet branding
  • Thinned up the exterior wall of the enclosure a bit. Changed the outside dims on the cover as well.
  • Removed the inner walls that the Duet installed on to and replaced with just some screw bosses. I did this both to save plastic and free up airflow.

print_settings.Notes:: I didn't try it with a lower resolution than 0.1mm, like e.g. 0.2mm. It just worked well with 0.1mm...

title: Rubber band airsoft cannon w/ magazine

description.text:
Just something my boys asked for. Suitable for standard BB/airsoft-bullets - for 5 ones to be precise.
Automatic reloading by pulling the "trigger" back to its end position. Might sometimes need a finger on top to prevent momentum let spill all of your cannonballs...

The parts are printable without support - just ensure orientation like shown in the picture. No raft needed. Dimensions are chosen that it works well without any rework.

If your tolerances will be different to mine I suggest to use some glue to fix the two endcaps at the rod. Different rubber band lengths can be used like shown in the picture.

Enjoy!

print_settings.Printer:: Wanhao Duplicator i3 Plus

description.text:
This is a beta design, you will need to free style some things a little bit to get this to work for you. Take my measurements with a grain of salt and MEASURE TWICE AND CUT ONCE!

I was not satisfied with the other Ikea Lack table enclosures so I set off to design my own. For me, this was a one off deal so the STL files are not 100% perfect but I received a few requests for my design anyways. I do not intend to build another one and no longer have the cad files so I will not be updating this.

The overall performance of this enclosure might be too good. I used foam tape to seal all of the gaps and tried to minimize the amount of air to escape. With the bed set to 60C degrees and my home set to 75F, the chamber will reach 95F after about an hour. This is warm enough to cause heat creep issues that I am currently trying to resolve. It also does an excellent job at cutting the noise down.

The Ikea tables are about 3" too short to fit over the wanhao i3 plus without a riser. You can print the riser but it's a waste of time and plastic in my opinion. I took the second Ikea table and cut the 3" off of each end of the legs. It is important to cut the ends off because the legs are actually hollow with end-blocks glued in. I screwed the four 3" extensions onto the uncut legs leaving the hollow side pointing down. The "EnclosureTopFoot" will plug into those legs. This allows you to pull the top of the enclosure off for what ever reason. I screwed the other 3" pieces onto the bottom of the table to raise it up. I intend to move the power supply to this area so it is not constantly in a heated chamber.

The 3 panels are just acrylic from the hardware store. These are on hinges so I can easily reach in to the enclosure and access the printer. The back is some type of fireproof aluminum foil covered cardboard from the local hardware store insulation section. I was originally going to mount a heat lamp to the back but did not have the room. The heatbed does a fine job at heating the chamber anyways. My front panel was 2" too short so I taped a second piece on :) (It was originally cut for the knock off version of the Lack table on Amazon)

The filament guide is not directly over the x axis gantry. I placed it about 6 inches back from the front edge of the chamber. I was hoping the filament path would be easier on the printer while minimizing the amount of air escaping. I suggest mounting your filament directly above the hole so it feeds straight in.

I use "The Ultimate Spool Holder" here https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2214740 and cut the little legs off. I screwed two 1/8th inch thick pieces of plywood (acrylic would do too) to the top to act as a holder to the TUSH.

Wanhao

1x 18x18" by 1/8th" thick cardboard with aluminum foil (found in insulation area of hardware store)

2x 17' 1/2" wide foam tape to form a gasket around the plastic panels

Hardware:
You will need a fair number of screws for this enclosure. You might want to print the parts out first then take them to the hardware store to see what works best for you

A few of the fasteners you need are:
6x 1/8th inch by 1" machine screws to hold the hinges together
12x counter sunk wood screws to hold the latch base to the printer
16x 1.5" #8 wood screws to hold the enclosure feet to the ikea table

title: MTG Deck Box with Dice Tray

description.text:
This is a deck box that I made for myself for my Magic the Gathering Commander deck. The main compartment perfectly fits (a little more snuggly than I had initially planned) my 100 card deck (single sleeved Dragon Shield), and the bottom compartment holds a number of token cards, as well as my dice (the largest of which is my Innistrad spindown D20).

The main compartment has a cutout to let you draw from the box and make it easier to get your cards out.

My printer isn't as accurate as I'd like it to be, so here are the dimensions of the files vs. what my printer built. Feel free to design your own lids as well.

Main compartment
Internal Width
File 68mm; Printed ~67.4mm
Internal Length
File 95mm; Printed ~94mm
Internal Depth
File 66mm; Printed ~66mm

Lower Compartment
Internal Depth
File 25; Printed ~24.5mm

Lip Design
Outer Lip - 2mm
Inner Lip - 2.7mm
Full Wall Thickness - 5mm

Printer Brand:

Wanhao

Printer:

Wanhao Duplicator i3 V2

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2 mm

Infill:

10%

Notes:

My printer is still pretty new, so it's not quite dialled in yet, and most of the problems I saw were from my machine (bowing on the bottoms since the bed is warped, etc.)

You may want supports on the main piece though because I didn't stop and think that having a 90 degree overhang on the bottom for the lip would be a problem. Whoops.

Built the box parts and designed the lip in Fusion 360. Also used the SVG to Sketch function in F360 to create the Magic logo on the lid.

Took the files into Tinkercad to round off the corners and add the honeycomb patterns.

Hi Mitpro,
in my Ender2 kit, the threaded rod was packed/protected inside a kind of hose/soft tube. Why not cut 5cm off and use this as protection ?
Even then, this solution has a big con: this tube has to be moved up and down for z-axis traveling.
A better idea is to keep the filament in a little distance to the rod, there are several parts doing exactly that here on thingiverse!

I simply designed it in the CAD program after detecting the problem without searching...
z travels in up direction are absolutly no problem. No increased resistance. At down movements the tube sticks a little bit and stays in the place.
I am afraid that the protection tube would be to soft and sticky :(

title: 40mm Side Fed Fan Cover - Fan Blades Protected

description.text:
This is a 40mm fan cover that is primary fed air via side channels. This prevents an allen key, filament, screw driver, etc. from breaking fan blades by slipping through front facing fan grills. The openings that are in the front only expose the fan hub, not the blades.

I was using a front fed design that was also tool-safe (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2600398) but the air flow through the fins was making the fan much noisier than usual. This design has wider channels side channels and keeps things quiet.

title: Tevo Little Monster Trike Adapter for Trucks/Carriages

description.text:
No denying, the carriages on the TLM require a fair amount of adjusting to achieve perfect tension with the added challenge of being equal across all three. I've attempted to take the guesswork out of it by designing an adapter that converts the carriage into a three-wheel configuration, provides consistent tension, and uses existing hardware.

I'm publishing this as a Work in progress so that fellow TLM patrons can help test this with me. Please post comments on your experience and any constructive criticism you may have. Thanks!!

UPDATE-V11
These might be the finals. I'm very happy with the results so far. They don't eliminate the concentric adjustments, but overall make it much easier to adjust. The little hole in the middle is not for a screw but to force the slicer to reinforce the area with outlines through the entire part. Instructions remain the same. After I apply to a couple more TLMs, I may update the instruction pics and deem this model complete while I figure something else out to make them self-adjusting.

UPDATE-V8
I tweaked the over length as it made it rather difficult to get the bolts through. I must've left it long for when I was dabbling with the suspension design. I also increased the height just slightly as I noticed tidbit of bowing when tightened. I don't believe it causes much of an issue but could rub off debris over time. Side note: I uploaded the wrong V8s, they have been corrected.

UPDATE-V7
I found the current design actually flexed to the point the posts would rub, so I made them stiff. If you want some flex it might be worth printing in semi-flex or nylon. I will still pursue a design that doesn't require adjustments of the concentric nuts, but at least with a trike the adjustment will be even across the 3 wheels.

Printer Brand:

SeeMeCNC

Printer:

Rostock MAX v2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.20 mm

Infill:

n/a

Notes:

Print with 5 outlines and you won't have infill. I recommend Taulman 910 Nylon. If you use something else, let me know how it turns out!

UPDATE
I've printed these in PETG and they work as well!

Carefully remove the three carriages from the printer and disassemble the two stationary wheels on each of them. We want the concentric wheels in place for potential adjustments. This is a great opportunity to inspect the wheels for wear and crunchiness. I recommend picking up some quality replacements (e.g. 3DVice). No additional hardware is necessary and you can use the same Allen wrench and open end wrench from your installation kit.

  1. Insert the Allen bolts through the carriage plate
  2. Squeeze the bottom adapter and slide onto the Allen bolts (like a bow)
  3. Place both brass washers on the bottom adapter post
  4. Place the bearing on the bottom post
  5. Press the locking nuts into the top adapter
  6. Place the top adapter and loosely tighten the bolts to allow some movement for flexing
  7. Adjust the two concentric nuts on the other two wheels to furthest position away from each other.
  8. Rinse and repeat for the remaining carriages
Eccentric concentric nuttiness. All ready to go; well, after I finish the other two and put the printer together. They should hold their own weight with little effort to slide up and down with absolutely NO bearing crunchiness.

description.text:
This is my go at a CNC / PCB Router started to learn how to use fusion360 and had a few parts from my old prusa i3 to D-bot build and the D-bot design gave me some pointers on fixing the frame together. i'm working on assembly instructions which i'll finalise when the open builds extrusion arrives in a week or so. most of the plastic parts could be replaced with opens builds brackets the exception being the motor mounts which would take a bit of fiddling.
for strength you should use ABS or PET-G the latter being my choice.
flakey with this many parts so don't be surprised when it crashes when adding or changing things.

i'll pop the design files up over the next few days note that the full assembly model takes an age to move anything i assume due to the nuts and bolts but individual parts are easy to change.

The fusion 360 archive file is now there and i'll update as i finish new bits off if someone can let me know that it uploads and unpacks ok as i just exported from the fusion hub and put the file on here note fusion gets a bit

The Aluminum plate could be printed , not used by just attaching the mounts to the 2080 but its not expensive and should give a strong stable bed.

UPDATED
i have rotated the .stl files to best position to print also added the aluminium plate .stl if you want to print instead of buying and drilling.

Added initial BOM this may change once the aluminium profile arrives.

i have added updates section below

Still to do

  1. add an optional mount on the back of the z axis motor mount with wheel bearings running along the 2040 beam this should allow a bigger spindle motor. (done)
  2. add end stop mounts. (done)
  3. add vacuum dust removal.
  4. finish esp32 grbl wifi bridge and electronics case

Note that the corner brackets are based on the open builds aluminium brackets that should be a drop in replacement if you don't want to print them. also the D-bot corner brackets https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1001065 should also drop in although i haven't tried them
