description.text:
I must start by saying that this is a work in progress. I have not completed this project as of yet, but will in the future. Feel free to use these things to create your own weather station. This is also just one piece of an entire weather station I am building. The full station has sensors for wind speed, wind direction, 8 inch rain gauge, temperature and humidity. This documentation may be heavily modified in the future.

This model is very complex and has all of the pieces to create a combined wind speed and direction sensor. This was all created in OpenSCAD. The anemometer.scad file can be modified for all pieces of this build.

Printer:

Anet A8

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Notes:

I printed this using eSun white PETG filament. I had read that the eSun filament had some UV resistant chemicals in the plastic which I figured would help with the longevity of the gauge as it will be out in the sun and other elements.

I designed this from searching different parts on thingiverse, reading articles on other DIY weather stations that people have done and put my own twist on some of it. Feel free to modify any of the parts on this build. The anemometer.scad file was used to create all of the .stl files found in this build. This part of the weather station has 2 functioning sensors. One for wind speed, and the other for wind direction. I had seen other builds that combined these two sensors and it looked like a good way of doing it.

Some of the pictures shown are part of the original design which has been modified a bit. The main design changes were to the wind direction sensor. I tried 3 different designs for getting the wind direction. The first was a magnetic reed sensor with a rotating magnet approach. Next was an infrared sensor approach, The final approach that I settled on was the AS5047 magnetic direction sensor.

Inside the upper and lower case pieces there are two ball bearing assemblies to hold the rotating sensors. These bearings are pointed out in the image below. The bearings give both sensors smooth rotation which is one of the keys for this sensor assembly.

At this point I am not going to go into much detail on all of the different parts, but as I get into finishing the weather station build I will update information in here as I get things more to a completed stage.

Check out the other parts of the weather station build:
Radiation shield : https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2758516
Tipping bucket rain gauge : https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2757560

Contact:

I see that there are quite a few people that have collected this. Feel free to post comments and let me know how your build went and if you had successes or failures. I have not fully finished the full weather station build, so I am curious to hear of people that have gotten this working.

.oO ENJOY Oo.

author: CANNAGAR_TOOLS

title: Holders for iPhone and Samsung phone

description.text:
We were playing with our new drone, a DJI Spark. We had an iPhone 6 and a Samsung Galaxy phone. We found this holder on Thingiverse, but it was too big for my printer, which is only a ProFab mini (same as MonoPrice Select Minin), so I started playing around with it. I cut the base away, then made horizontal and vertical pieces to hold the phones.

The vertical piece slots into a box at the back of the base. It is slightly loose, so I wrapped one layer of duct tape around it, and it has just the right fit and friction.

The first iteration was for the iPhone. The two pieces are glued together, and the phone slots in by springing the horizontal bar back.

The second one is for the Samsung; slide the phone between the top and bottom flanges of the vertical piece, then slide the horizontal bar down behind the phone to lock it in place.

This was all done on TinkerCad, and I have made the files public, so they will be easy to adjust for any other size device.

I saved them all in one file here to make it simpler, but was then asked for separate files, so there are also now five files, one for each item.

title: Dagoma NEVA XL spool holder arm

description.text:
I liked the Dagoma Neva spool support by Achrome that I found on Thing I verse and I likes the spool holder clip by Phende, so thought I would give them a try. Turns out that most of my filament comes in reels that are much wider than the what the spool holder arm was designed for, so I did a remix of the reel arm to make it long enough for any reel of filament. Also the little locking swivel pin on the support arm is not the way I would do things. I would put the locking pin or this case make it a locking cam on the top of the support arm and put a mating slot on the top of the main clip. But what I did was put in my longer support arm and just make a mark on the arm that lined up with the keyway on the main body clip. Then just drilled a small hole and put in a finnish nail as the locking pin, all near the top.
Thanks guys for this design as it has made the printer foot print much smaller and easy to move around.

description.text:
We use lots of plastic cups from IKEA, because we have small children. The only annoyance about them is that they often flip inside the dishwasher, fill up with water and don't really get washed.

I've designed this simple clamp that will hold the cup in place. Not sure if it will fit your dishwasher and cup size, but it's a very quick and cheap print.

Do not use PLA for this thing, as it will likely warp due to the high temperatures inside the dishwasher.

Introduction:

A variation of the Grab Toy ++ (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2750749) that turns 180 degrees. For this I needed to determine the length of the longer arms on the right as a function of totalArmLength (which is the lenght used for the left side). Since those arm lengths are not the distances between the axes of the hinges there is a bit of math to do (line 324 of the OpenSCAD file), but that's pretty much it.

To finish it up I added some text for decoration.

Main routine:

TheMadCobra(): generates the Mad Cobra model.

Included STL file:

TheMadCobra_slack05.stl: a render of the Mad Cobra using 0.5mm spacing for the hinges.

Enjoy!

description.text:
EDIT: I've completely redesigned this and posted it as a new thing. https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2795254

This is a design for mounting film rollers at the top and bottom of a 4" wide PVC pipe. This is part of a larger project in building a continuous processing machine for 16mm motion picture film.

This model is designed around VEtienne's model "35mm + 16mm Sprocket Roller Package (1/4" d-shaft bore)"

Printer:

Monoprice Delta Mini

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Infill:

10%

Notes:

The big flat side should face down. I'm not sure why Fusion 360 keeps exporting my models on their side. You'll need to rotate it 90 degrees after import.

In addition to printing this, you'll also want to print VEtienne's rollers. I used the "Free roller smooth" because in my design the film is driven only by a motor at the end of the film, which slowly pulls it through the machine.

Mount the rollers using 1/4" machine screws as axles. Depending on the hole size your printer makes, you may be able to thread the screw directly into the print and not need a nut on the other side.

The bottom assembly should fit inside the bottom of your PVC pipe. I'm using a two-foot section because that holds just over a gallon of solution. It's also easier to loop film around the bottom roller for a shorter pipe, because it will be installed permanently at the bottom.

Slide an end cap over the bottom of the pipe with the bottom roller assembly in place. This should fit smoothly and prevent the bottom roller assembly from moving. Once you have made sure the whole thing fits together, use PVC cement to install the end cap. (Otherwise solution will leak out the bottom and make a mess.)

The upper roller assembly should sit on top of the pipe. It doesn't need to be cemented in place.
I imported a model of a 4" x 2' PVC pipe into Fusion 360 from McMaster-Carr's website. I also imported VEtienne's roller model, and modeled a shape that would adapt the two together.
Customized version of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:58001 Created with Customizer! http://www.thingiverse.com/apps/customizer/run?thing_id=58001

title: Pfister_974-250 valve case
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
After having a hard time finding a replacement valve for my sink, getting the wrong from H.D. online, returning it, and buying a new faucet, it occurred to me on my drive home, that I have a 3D printer and the outer shell of the valve is what's broke (disintegrated), I can take this opportunity to learn some design and print a new one.

So I did. After a couple of modifications and sanding, I got it on the second try. I returned the faucet, and saved myself almost $200!!

While talking to a guy in line at H.D. about designing this, he said "Dang man, you got me thinking I need to go buy me a 3D Printer now!" I should have told him about the custom switch panels. He would have been sold! LOL

Printer:

Tevo Tarantula

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.15

Infill:

25

Notes:

Make sure to print with the small cylinder down. It is less support, less cleanup, and the 'square parts' print square.

Sand & Trim

After printing I had to sand the inside of the small cylinder so the switch would fit, and trim the 'square hole' around the guide block until it fit properly.

123D Design

I've been wanting to learn some designing, so I took this opportunity to utilize what I've learned so far in 123D Design. Without getting into too much detail.

I drew a reasonable likeness to the part, measured the original part section by section, then started adding the primitive shapes I needed. After having the basic outline, I created the inside shape with primitives, and merged then subtracted them away. Lastly, for the interior "parts" I created some primitives in the shapes I needed, and merged them in the appropriate spots.

I recommend the C3 Library videos for anyone wanting to learn 123D fast. It's older software, but I felt it was a good step up from Tinkercad.

title: Lever Door Knob Small Child Safety Stopper

description.text:
I needed simple, aesthetically pleasing a non-permanent and no-drill solution to stop our 1.5 year old from opening lever doors in our apartment.

These stop the lever from pivoting down, and most children who NEED child safety devices, aren't tall enough to lift the lever high enough to disengage the latch. I now have them on all of our doors, and so does a family member. Working wonderfully so far.

I've tried them on a variety of brands and styles of lever knobs. So far I haven't come across one that didn't fit.

Left and right are included. I recommend placing it on the side most likely to be grabbed. Typically on the outside of the door.

Hex infill at 25% or more will suffice for strength if printing in PLA.

title: Prusa i3 as router CNC - Y axis direct drive

description.text:
This design is not from me. I adapted it from giulio prelli's. Congratulations, Giulio!
You can improve the accuracy of Y axis of your Prusa by using direct drive method.
As always, all the bearings are 608ZZ and rods 8mm. The frame is 6mm

Upgrade 22/01/2018:
I would want to remark that the thing is only for router CNC, NOT for 3DP. So, please think twice before make comments.
We do know that 3DP need high speed on X and Y axis. This is not the case.
This thing comes to replace the X and Y mechanisms of a Prusa structure for using as router CNC machine.
Most of the machining centers use a similar scheme: direct coupling between motor and axis, through shaft coupling. Only low/poor quality machining centers use belt transmision. This is because in machining centers you need precision more than speed. Also you need a stronger structure to avoid vibrations from the spindle.

In machining centers, the axis is led by two bearings at each end. They make all the force to sustain the axis.

As machining centers have, the axis of this design has two support points (one near to the motor and other at the end), and one traction point (at the table).
The point of the table has two nuts in order that reduce the backlash. Note that there are only 4 screws for fixing the two nuts. You can adjust them more or less to increase/reduce the backlash.
Use please rectified screw, like I show in the pictures.

The mechanism also will work fine without the bearing at the end of the axis.
If you use it, you will be able to see that the bearing near the motor is firmly fixed by a screw, protecting the axis motor, but the other one is free, to permit any small movement.
Finally, the weight of the whole table is led by two brass brushing body.stl, so the axis wont support its weight at all.

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Clone

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

55%

Hello. Thank you very much for your comment. Your time and explanation are really apreciated!
First of all, I want to remark that the thing is only for router CNC, NOT for 3DP. So, please think twice before make comments about 3DP in this thing.
We do know that 3DP need high speed on X and Y axis. This is not the case.
This thing comes to replace the X and Y mechanisms of a Prusa structure for using as router CNC machine.
By reading this and other comments, now I am sure that additional images were missing to clarify the operation and the way of assembling. Because that I am adding them now.
Most of the machining centers use a similar scheme: direct coupling between motor and axis, through shaft coupling. Only low quality machining centers use belt transmision. This is because in machining centers you need precision more than speed. Also you need a stronger structure to avoid vibrations from the spindle.
I thing that you are wrong when say that the lead screw should be led only for coupling and nut points.
In machining centers, the axis is led by two bearings at each end. They make all the force to sustain the axis. Not the coupling (could damage the axis of the motor). Not the nuts of the table (they are very precise and expensive parts of the machine, mostly lubricated ball bearings)

title: LZ-129 Hindenburg - scale 1/1000
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
famous Air Ship

scale 1:1000



In my model series in 1:1000, the largest airship should not be missing.

History:
LZ 129 Hindenburg was a large German commercial passenger-carrying rigid airship, the lead ship of the Hindenburg class, the longest class of flying machine and the largest airship by envelope volume. It was designed and built by the Zeppelin Company (Luftschiffbau Zeppelin GmbH) on the shores of Lake Constance in Friedrichshafen and was operated by the German Zeppelin Airline Company .The airship flew from March, 1936 until it was destroyed by fire 14 months later on May 6, 1937 while attempting to land at Lakehurst Naval Air Station in Manchester Township, New Jersey at the end of the first North American transatlantic journey of its second season of service with the loss of 36 lives. This was the last of the great airship disasters; it was preceded by the crashes of the British R38 in 1921 (44 dead), the US airship Roma in 1922 (34 dead), the French Dixmude in 1923 (52 dead), the British R101 in 1930 (48 dead), and the US Akron in 1933 (73 dead).
(Source Wikipedia)

See what might come next

Instagram: https://www.instagram.com/vandragon_de

Support me :)

Although it is a lot of fun to draw boats and bring them to life, it takes a lot of time to research and draw. Especially the 1:1000 scale models are very time-consuming. So I wanted to see if there are any dear enthusiasts among you who appreciate my work and support me a little bit. Thank you for your help :)

description.text:
I loved Solajin's Solajin's Champions of Midgard (kickstarter box insert) but I use sleeved cards so needed to expand upon his creation to store my game. I am not a modeler yet so searched for customizable starting ideas and modified them in OpenSCAD to flesh out the rest of the storage solution.

To use this first print out Solajin's Champions of Midgard (kickstarter box insert) https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2555504

CoMKS_BoxSupport.stl holds the 3 component boxes from Solajin's build in a tower. Smallest box to largest. This was modified from: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1699258

CoMKS_LargeSleevedCards and CoMKS_SmallSleevedCards was modified from https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2120898/ after I measuring everything with my caliper about 47 times.

CoMKS_LeaderBoards was modified from https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2404395. The font is Norse.

CoMKS_SmallCardsRiser is a box I built to raise the small cards up 17mm to be easier to grab. After I printed them out and stuck them in (once they are in they are in for life) I realized printing them out in different colors would look better. You will need to print 5 of these.

Everything is 84mm high so that the game board will fit perfectly in the box and hold everything in when the game box is stored on the side.

You can fully customize each holder:

If you like it, also check out my configurable text based creations, text box with lid, name plate, etc. Or have a look at my configurable pack of dogs and rabbits.

print_settings.Notes:: https://www.makergeeks.com/products/raptor-series-pla-high-performance-3d-filament-hd-battleship-grey-175mm-1kg

description.text:
Simple graduated cylinder - with a twist! To make it easier to label, this is a graduated cylinder within a tower. Has pouring spouts on both sides, to accommodate left-headed or right-handed people.

This started out as a math exercise: determine the heights of various cylinders to hold different volumes.

Developing in ml is easy: each ml of volume fits in 1 cm^3. 1 cm = 10 mm, so 1 cm^3 = 1000 mm^3.

To convert to ounces, you need to know that 1 fluid ounce = 29.574 ml.

For a cylinder, the volume is base height. The area of the base is pi (r^2).

To fit on a small footpring printer (I use a Monoprice Select Mini) with maximum x, y, and z of 120 mm, I decided that I would create a cylinder of the appropriate radius to that each 10mm in height equaled 1 ounce.

So, V= pi * (r^2)

rearranging the equation to solve for r: sqrt(V/pi) = r

if Volume = 29.574, then r = sqrt(29.574/pi)
r = sqrt(29.574/3.1416)
r= sqrt(9.4137)
r = 3.068

Since r= 3.068, then the diameter of the base = 2*r = 6.136 cm
6.136 cm = 61.36 mm

Printer:

Monoprice Select Mini

Notes:

May have to experiment with Infill percentages, but 20% infill should suffice for most uses. If you are going to use this for food prep, make sure that you use food-safe materials, especially materials that can hold up to high temperatures used for cleaning. Regular PLA would not be very useful, as it will deform (has a glass transition temperature) around 60-65 degrees C, so it would not likely hold up to a dishwasher that heats water - or has a heated dry cycle. Heat-resistant PLA, however, can withstand 110 degrees C without deforming. One such filament is MakerGeeks Raptor PLA:

https://www.makergeeks.com/products/raptor-series-pla-high-performance-3d-filament-hd-battleship-grey-175mm-1kg

title: Cover for Future electronic's Creative board (Microsemi SmartFusion2 / Igloo2, blue and yellow boards)

description.text:
Has exposed headers for Arduino shields, xbee mikrobus and pmod devices.

The design is parametric and could be adjusted for regular Arduino as well.

The cover needs to be flipped by 180 degree before printing (but then it will not need any support to print well). Tested with 0.3mm layer height and PLA, the cover is not super strong and without base it can be bent a bit, but it's not for physical protection as much as for the short circuit protection.

title: The Ultimate Spool Holder i3 mod

description.text:
I took delivery of my new i3 Mk3 and it comes also with the new spool holder, but, it didn't really fit and so I decided to look for what else there is out there on Thingiverse.

I really liked the TUSH - The Ultimate Spool Holder design https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2047554, but, it needs to sit on a flat surface so I modified the design to fit on the i3 frame. I see there is already a suitable remix of the design https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2539560, but, it keeps the same fixing design as the original Prusa spoolholders - which break when moved around / has additional complication of four parts plus added bolt fixings.

There are also other frame mounted designs; like https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1808192 and https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1832235 which seem very good, but, they don't have the simple elegance of the TUSH design.

If you print 2 off the regular v2 and 2 off the re-mix v3 then these snap into the 608 bearings and mount on the frame without any screws. Seems quite elegant and works like a dream so far.

MK3

Printer:

Prusa i3

Notes:

I used higher infill on the v3 version for strength and 20% on the TUSH v2 version.

Depending on the type of filament you use (I've tried PETG and PLA) there can be shrinkage issues impacting dimensions. If you have trouble to fit the bearings (part too tight) then try printing at 98% (or too loose 102%). I used a G-clamp to force the parts together.

description.text:
This is a remix of SavageRodent's Outer Ring Customizer SCAD for Combination Safe 00 (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:586169).

The original included:

Adjustable Parameters:
Characters (any number, letter or symbol)
Font
Font Style (bold & italic)
Font Size
Text rotation
Emboss or engrave text
Depth (amount to which characters are embossed or engraved).

I've added the ability to set font and font size by character. This started due to a font I was using having numerals in different sizes than alpha characters at the same font size. Then I figured it'd be fun to allow for more varying combinations. Make rings with several fonts, but only have a single (different) sans serif font on each ring. The spelled word could be gibberish, but the solution is sans serif (or serif, or monospace, or whatever)
Cool little symbols to go above your desk!

description.text:
This is an air squeegee designed based on recommendations in Kodak's H-24 processing modules for motion picture film. (Module 2, page 5)

The purpose of this print is to dry 16mm motion picture film as it passes through a processing machine, to reduce cross-contamination of chemical baths. The drying is accomplished by creating an "air knife" through which the film passes. Ideally these are installed in pairs, one for each side of the film.

Later I will update this model to have some mounting features. Currently it has none because I haven't decided how to mount it in the processing machine.

UPDATE: I've narrowed the exit passage and added a fillet to some internal edges. This is reflected in the airknife3.stl file with the "V2" mark on top.

UPDATE2: I've added a new model file, for a bracket that'll make it easy to mount a pair of the blowers onto a punched flat bar frame with 3/4" spaced 3/8" diameter holes. The blowers should be glued onto the flat platform so that they have a narrow space in between. The bracket also holds film rollers that align the film with the dryer passage. The bracket was designed to fit these rollers by VEtienne.

Printer:

Monoprice Delta Mini

Infill:

20%

Notes:

Flip the model 90 degrees to lay the model flat with the circular hole and text on top.

You'll want to minimize stringing and excess plastic blobs inside the narrow air passages, so the retraction settings on your printer will be important.
The circular hole on top of the model is designed to accept an 1/8" NPTF tap. I use this to attach a barbed brass hose fitting for 3/16" rubber tubing. (Part number 5346K11 from McMaster-Carr)

title: Weighted SMD Soldering Hold Down Tool

description.text:
This is a weighted hold down tool for soldering SMD components.

Quick demo of the tool here
https://www.instagram.com/p/Bd8ZmlgFbXa/?taken-by=tableft_workshop
https://www.instagram.com/p/Bd7CzYulr4x/?taken-by=tableft_workshop

The arm and axle are made from 1/8" bar (i think 3mm will work fine) the arm was sharpened and bent to the desired shape and glued into the pivoting arm. I ream the holes out with a dill to clean them up and get them to the right fit ( use one step up drill size for the pivoting arm holes so its loose). afterward just fill the cavities with something heavy, I used BB's but it could be lead shot, sand, small nuts & bolts whatever you have on hand.

Feel free to remix and improve http://a360.co/2DvMzRG

print_settings.Printer:: R1 ABS + PLA Model

description.text:
My version of extended landing gear for the DJI spark. I made these as a two piece design for ease of printing.

Requires 3 M2 x 6mm bolts per leg

Insure the motor mount holes are cleared out to be a true clearance hole and use the bolt to tape into the lower leg. I used a 1.5mm drill bit to help clear out the holes that need to self tap. I also used CA glue to help secure the two parts, they should never come apart. You could also probably use a nut if you think it would be more secure, i just didn't want to add more weight.

As much as i do not like ABS i found it to be the best material for these extended landing gear, i tried PETG but broke them as i tried to fit onto the spark.

Clean the inside of the motor mount up with sand paper and push and twist on, i pushed the outside on as far as possible and then seated the side towards the body to be as flush as possible with the arm.

title: Raspberry Pi IR-Cut Camera Mount for Robotic Arm

description.text:
Τhis is a Raspberry Pi camera module mount that I designed for the SainSmart 6-Axis Desktop Robotic Arm.

This is not designed for the regular camera module though, but rather for the IR-CUT version which has an IR filter that can be switched on or off with a GPIO pin. The camera module can be easily found, by searching for raspberry pi ir-cut camera module on eBay.

The regular camera module has the mounting holes on different places, however the FreeCAD design file is available for download so you can change that if you want.

title: Alpha-Class Star Wing x2 and x3 Holder (X-Wing Miniatures) for Stanley organizer

description.text:
Thanks to batman202020 and Shagbert for doing test prints of the face up version! It is actually Shagberts picture used in the galery, thanks for his permission to put it there.

I use the Stanley 25-Compartment Organizers for my X-Wing Miniatures collection, this is part of my bin set. I do own all but the Scum ships, so there will be bins for them at some point.

My design goals:

  • Maximize Space
  • Attractive Presentation
  • Include the movement dials

So, here is my design for the Alpha-Class Shuttle.

This will fit the Stanley 25 Compartment Organizer (https://amzn.com/B00005QWYF) or the Harbor Freight 20 Compartment version (https://www.harborfreight.com/tool-storage/part-storage/19-bin-portable-parts-storage-case-93928.html).

As I complete and post more of this collection, I will link them here as well. The List also includes links to Lord_Dwonkins bin collection, his designs were the starting point of this bin series. Thanks for the concept.

title: Doc Brown's Stopwatch (Back to the Future)

description.text:
This is an approximation of Doc Brown's Seiko stopwatch from Back to the Future. To fully recreate the look from the movie, you'll want to add in a red LED numeric display. The model is designed around this display from Adafruit.

The production team for the movie actually made the original prop by gutting a Seiko and replacing the LCD display with the LED digits so it would show up on camera. Unless you're going for maximal authenticity this is an alternative to sourcing and gutting a valuable vintage stopwatch!

There should be enough room for one of the smaller arduinos and for a battery holder, for which there is an access hole on the back plate.
After printing, glue the face plate to the body. Add in the electronics, and glue the back plate on to complete the prop.

author: Mylakovich

description.text: I needed a simple, low profile, adjustable light for a project and decided it was easiest to just make my own. All the parts were surplus from other projects. I just had to make the structural parts. Laser cutting was easiest and quickest, so with parts in hand, and specific measurements for my project, designing the parts was pretty easy. I wanted it to be as adjustable as possible so a multi-arm design seemed best. I salvaged the LED strips from an exhibit being replaced at work and the switch from a collection of spare parts.

I use the free version of Draftsight (since I sometimes teach classes at work, and want kids to have easy access to the software we use) which is pretty easy to use and very versatile. For the structure, I was designing around the parts I had on hand and the specific need. I wanted the design to be adaptable as well.

I used #6-32 x 3/4" bolts and nuts with a nylon washer between each arm. I added cable tie holes on the arms to wrangle the wire. The arms are made from 2.2" (5.5mm) thick birch ply with 3 different pieces - a 1" arm used to attach to the base and head, 4" arm, and an 8" arm. The LED strip was originally one piece, so after cutting to size, I just soldered the sections back in series. I'll use a standard 12v wall wart to power it.

If I were to do this again, I think I would make the base a little larger and heavier. I made the base from the same plywood as the arms and should have used something thicker to give it more weight. If the lamp is cantilevered out too much it will fall over. Luckily for my application I needed something tall and skinny.... I guess I could glue some weights under the base to weigh it down. (After playing with it a bit, the base is definitely too light to support the arm...I would use thicker material.)

print_settings.Notes:: I printed this using eSun white PETG filament.  I had read that the eSun filament had some UV resistant chemicals in the plastic which I figured would help with the longevity of the gauge as it will be out in the sun and other elements.

description.text:
This is part two of my weather station. I must start by saying that this is a work in progress. I have not completed this project as of yet, but will in the future. Feel free to use these things to create your own weather station. This is also just one piece of an entire weather station I am building. The full station has sensors for wind speed, wind direction, 8 inch rain gauge, temperature and humidity. This documentation may be heavily modified in the future.

This is my version of a tipping bucket rain gauge. This was all created in OpenSCAD. The tipping_bucket_rain_gauge.scad file can be modified for all pieces of this build.

Printer:

Anet A8

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Notes:

I printed this using eSun white PETG filament. I had read that the eSun filament had some UV resistant chemicals in the plastic which I figured would help with the longevity of the gauge as it will be out in the sun and other elements.

This build was done from researching other commercially sold rain gauges, and researching information from weather websites. The funnel for this rain gauge is an 8 inch diameter, so you should have at least a 220mm x 220mm build plate on your 3D printer to make this. There are four main parts to the rain gauge, the base, base mounting support, the tipping bucket and of course, the funnel cover. The tipping bucket has a small recessed hole in one top corner which holds a magnet. The upright piece on the base is used to hold a magnetic reed switch. The concept is that for every tip of the bucket, the reed switch is triggered. Every trigger of the reed switch indicates an amount of water. By counting the tips of the bucket over a period of time you can calculate the amount of rainfall within that period.

I have not completed this project yet, so as I get more done I will modify the information here. For now, feel free to grab any of the build files and make your own.

At this point I am not going to go into much detail on all of the different parts, but as I get into finishing the weather station build I will update information in here as I get things more to a completed stage.

Check out the other parts of the weather station build:
Radiation shield : https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2758516
Wind speed and direction sensor : https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2757369

title: Bitcoin and crypto currency tamper-proof paper wallet

description.text:
These are quick and easy to print crypto currency tamper-proof paper wallet containers.

This is a really simple and elegant physical wallet. It's tamper-proof so you can be assured the private key has not be seen. It is easily broken open for when you want to use it.

Print QR codes for both the wallet address and private key. Ensure only the wallet address is showing.

Use a translucent filament color so you can see the QR code through the container (see photo). The QR code readers have no problem reading the QR code through the container.

Put a stopping point or filament color change in your print at around 3mm so you can insert the QR codes before the container is sealed up with your QR code inside.

Or, you can print without qr codes and use them as conversation starters to help spread the word about crypto currencies.

Let me know what other coin or token you'd like to see and I'll add it to the list.

Print at .3 with no infill so it goes fast (12 minutes). My prusa spans the 30mm distance with no infill just fine.

Put a small dab of super glue on the QR code to keep it flush with the bottom of the coin so that it shows through clearly. It also helps the extruder fan from blowing the QR code out while printing :-)

I use QR Monkey to create the QR Codes. Make sure you test reading the QR codes before you use them. Some QR generators are funky and I couldn't read the QR codes they produced.
https://www.qrcode-monkey.com/#bitcoin

title: Ikea Daybed - Anker Soundcore - Cellphone Mount

description.text:
A mount for the Anker Soundcore or Soundcore 2 speakers to hang over the edge of a door/shelf/etc. This one is sized for my Ikea daybed, and has some springs integrated because I found the bass of the Soundcore 2 to be a bit much when actually laying in the bed. The springs GREATLY reduce the transmitted bass to the bed frame.

The holes are sized for a wire coat hangar. If you strip the insulation on the coated coat hangars back, the wire fits snugly into the holes, and a dab of cyanoacrylate glue keeps it in place.

Updated: Added a generic cellphone mount version as well.

This is a difficult print for FDM printers. As such it will require some clean up after the fact. I printed it on a 0.4mm nozzle, but if you can, try to print it on a 0.25mm nozzle. Beyond that, I'd recommend using an SLA printer for this since they are great at high detail jobs.
If using an FDM printer, you will want to using some sanding twigs to clean it up since there will be stringing.

title: Durafly Tundra RC Airplane Tail Strut Supports

description.text:
Remix of the tail strut supports for the Hobby King Durafly Tundra. The ones provided in the kit are very flimsy and broke when gluing.

I redesigned the tail strut support so you do not have to cut any foam and do not need supports while printing.

Use the carbon fiber tail struts provided with the model but remove the heat shrink. Glue the carbon fiber strut into the top and bottom strut supports. Ensure you have the correct strut supports glued to each other.

Sand the bottom of the strut support a few times with 100 grit sandpaper to rough up the surface. Clean all joining surfaces with rubbing alcohol and glue with E6000 glue. Clamp overnight and let the glue dry.

Drill a small hole in the plastic on each side of the tail and insert the provided screws.

Printer:

ANET A8

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

35

description.text:
Inspired by the Form Wash, I was really looking for a cleaning solution that would allow me to drop the build platform into something to clean to avoid the messy removal process. While not as elegant as the Form Wash, this meets that goal at a fraction of the cost.

This is an adapter plate to allow the Form2 build plate to soak in a Cambro 6 QT square container. Allows you to drop your Form2 build plate in a Cambro Square 6QT for IPA washing. Fits this container: http://a.co/hgRFOGL

I used this with a magnetic stirrer I purchased on Ebay to get a nice washing machine effect. I drop my build plate in, clean it for 15-20 mins and then my Form2 build platform and printed part is clean and ready for removal.

Video example: https://youtu.be/fqCVqngKbgI

title: Panzerhund Robot Attack Dog
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Wanted a big Panzerhund like in the Wolfenstein games, the original model form the game was a bit complicated so I designed my own. Just think of it as a prototype to the ones in the game.

I'm still in the process of printing this so some things may change.

1/14/2018: Left out a socket, instructions to come once I finish the printing
1/15/2018: I feel pretty confident no changes will be needed so added the Fusion360 backup file.
1/16/2018: Neck Socket was not modeled correctly, uploaded a new version, fusion backup file is not up to date at this time.
1/16/2018: The socket inserts on the leg joints were a bit weak so I have increased the base size.
1/18/2018: Completed most of the printing, turned out good except the leg joints are too loose to support the weight. I think in a redesign in the future I will move to using hardware to connect the legs together so that tension on the joint can be adjusted.

1/28/2018: Late update, work has ben busy, new leg joint design finished, going to be testing it soon. It will use rubber washers and screw compression to add resistance. V2 has been added, though it has not been tested yet, so things may change.

1/29/2018: Fixed the Joint length, printing a test of the joint tonight, so please hang in there, V1 is still available as a zip file acrhive.

2/19/2018: Test Printing the front legs with the new joints, the rubber for the washer I am using is:
https://www.amazon.com/Styrene-Butadiene-Rubber-Backing-Thickness/dp/B00L8NRV2S/

2/20/2018: Updated Lock for joint, also added a B and C version, each with 1 and 2mm depth increase for more locking. Added O-ring for external compression, type 110 3/32, 3/8" ID 9/16" OD. Details on drawing. Assembly drawings for Panzerhund coming soon. Locking joints work well, as seen in picture, moving on to Neck joint next, then body V2 for more sleek look.

2/22/2018: Uploaded new version of neck, lower/upper jaw, and body. (lock for body to neck joint is coming in the next day)

Ordered these o-rings to tryn out for this and future models:
https://www.amazon.com/110-Ring-Durometer-Black-Width/dp/B000MN9T3O/
Ordered this gasket punch set to try out:
https://www.amazon.com/Lang-Tools-950-11-Piece-Gasket/dp/B000I1IWVA/

Will update on how they work

title: Philips 212/312 Turntable phono Cartridge Alignment Tool

description.text:
This is a Phono Cartridge Alignment tool for a vintage Philips Model 212 or 312 turntable. When this turntable was new back in the 70's and 80's, an alignment tool was supplied with the turntable to get the phono cartridge set up properly. The phono cartridge was installed onto the black sled and the sled was inserted into the alignment tool. The phono stylus was then adjusted to line up at the cross section of the v notch and the front face of the cantilever.
I reverse engineered the tool from the two critical dimensions I had. The last picture shows the proper position of the phono stylus I have tried it and it gets my cartridge aligned for proper tracking.

Removing Supports

I found it's easiest to remove the supports using flush cutters.

Using my calipers, I took measurements of the Pro Plate and sketched an adapter that it would slide into. The plate didn't fit into the first version, so I double-checked my measurements and rounded the vertical edges to get rid of sharp corners. The second version didn't have enough flex, so I increased the amount of material cut underneath the tab. At this point, I had a functional print, but it was much larger than it needed to be, so I decreased the size - this fourth version is the one that I use and the one that is in the picture. I realized as I was uploading the files that one of the fillets got removed when I decreased the size, so I added it back in before uploading the stl.

author: xPedrox6

print_settings.Printer:: Wanhao Duplicator i3 V2

description.text:
This is is a "Fan Tunnel" for stacking Fanless Gridseed Orbs (5 Chip ASIC Crypto Currency Miners). If your Orbs have fans, it is fine just to take them off as this design will keep them cool using only one or two fans. Assembly is a screw-less design. FYI this thing is BIG, and chews through a lot of filament, but the base is secure enough to hold several Orbs stacked.

Currently what is shown here is the base, and the Gridseed mount. Assembly is as follows:

  1. Place the 80mm fan onto the base, using the friction clips on the fan-shrowd base. Make sure that the fan blows UP. On most fans there is an arrow indicating airflow, if not the rule of thumb is It will always blow towards the structural plastic side.
  2. Place the Gridseed Mount onto the baseplate, using the friction clips on the base
  3. Place the First FANLESS Gridseed Orb into the Gridseed Mount.

I have not finished the stacking components yet, but this should get you started.

BTW: This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/liUgc0CKBBe

title: Dicegamon Board Game
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Designed by Ken Maher (https://kenmgames.wordpress.com/). Move your dice around ... and then off ... the board before your opponent does the same.
Set-up - You will need the 8-on-a-side Backgammon board supplied or a regular board shortened. Each player will need 12 dice (in a different color or style) and an additional two dice. Each player sets up their dice as in Figure 1 – On the far side of the board, in front of their opponent.
Moving - On a player's turn they roll the two movement dice. The numbers that come up are the type of dice that may be moved. If doubles are rolled two pieces may each be moved or one piece moved twice (no stopping between moves). When doubles are rolled the player also gets to take an additional turn.
Dice indicated for movement may travel a number of spaces equal to or less than the value of that die. A die may always be placed on a column containing your own dice. Dice may only land on a column with opponent's dice if their die is of equal or greater value than all the dice in that column.
You will need to print the Board twice

author: Anubis_

title: Screwdriver/Pen Holster(redesigned)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a redesign of my original screwdriver holster. I've made many improvements from the original. Specifically... The orientation is turned 90 degrees. The interior of the belt clip is no longer square(I was getting breakage due to the sharp interior corners, so it is now an arch which hasn't failed during usage yet). redesigned to fit the new Xcelite R181 screwdriver that I recently purchased(slightly larger handle than my old one). I added 2 small detentes inside of the area for the Pen(to give a better grip on the pen cap which avoids having the pen fall out). lastly, I added small windows for the screwdriver and pen clips to get a more aggressive capture.
It still fits Pilot or Uni-ball pens and the Multi-bit screwdrivers found at Menards/Home Depot.
This orientation also requires very little support.

Up!

Up Mini

author: Dodger60

title: Prop Zombrex Autoinjector
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
A zombrex autoinjector prop, based on the game series Dead Rising. Some stylistic guidance from the old style epipen autoinjectors with 'blue to the sky, orange to the thigh' instructions.

Built using 3/4" SCH40 PVC pipe, and some M3 screws and locknuts. You may need to adjust the lower retainer size to friction fit into SCH40 PVC pipe dependent upon the tolerances of your pipe.

The upper cap is a single piece print which is glued into the pipe. The lower requires assembly and M3 screw assembly, though there's no specific reason why it couldn't be re-designed for single piece printing. Once built it was no longer a priority, so this is as far as it will go.

The label was printed on a Dymo labelwriter label, and has been provided in the format for their software.

If you are making one of these, consider sending a tip - every dollar helps to create more things like this and encourage more open sourcing of designs.

author: aonomus

description.text:
I had a desire to make some small chain drives for some of my models, but wanted to use some classic chain link style chair rather than proper chain drive chain. I had a look on thingiverse and discovered that nobody else had made a model for this. So, after scratching around with a pencil to work out what parameters I needed, I jumped on OpenSCAD and came up with two parametric models. This one has a neck, holes and nut slots for screwing it onto a shaft while the other is just a disk with the chain recesses which can be more easily adapted to other pulley body designs.

The chain size and number of link pairs determines the size of the pulley. So the important variables to fiddle with are;

Llength: This is the outside length dimension of a single link
Lwidth: This is the outside width dimension of a single link
Lthickness: This is the diameter of the link “wire”

N: The number of chain link pairs around the pulley. Please note this is pairs of links not the number of single links.

The pulley neck size is controlled by the following parameters;

Pwidth: Width of the pulley main drum which the chain recesses are cut into.
PstemD: This is the diameter of the pulley attachment neck. There is nothing to stop you putting dimensions in here that can't accommodate the retaining screw or the shaft. We leave that to you, the user, to figure something sensible.
PneckL: This is the desired neck length

AxleD: This is the axle diameter
ScrewD: This is the retaining screw diameter

There are a bunch of other parameters that you may wish to tweak too;

Ptol: Is the printing tolerance. It is used to provide a bit of space around the chain profile so that chain will fit into the recess despite a bit of spread from the extruded plastic.
PtolThk: This is a printing allowance for the "radially" orientated link thickness. This allows a bit of extra on either side of the link slot so any sagging of the printed filament can be easily removed or at least won't interfere with the link sliding into the slot.
Wclr: On either side the the tangential link is a cutout slot. This parameter just controls the size of this slot.

CutD:There are some very stylish decorative holes in the end of the pulley. This parameter controls the diameter of these.
CutN: This controls the number of these extremely stylish holes.

Hopefully this is all clear enough.

I feel the model will work well for larger chains where the printing tolerances are less of a factor in the final printed shape.

I trust this will be useful to you.

remixed_from.author: balloneta
remixed_from.title: Steam Controller-Dongle Battery Door-Internal Wit logo

title: Steam USB Dongle Holder Battery Cover

description.text:
A remix of balloneta's and CLB1's designs. When I printed the battery cover on my printer I ran into several problems. After much tweaking and prototyping, I finally got a model which works perfectly on my printer. Here is what I changed:

  • Tongs at the top are slightly farther apart. (They were printing a bit too close to fit)
  • Added clips to dongle holder to keep it from falling out. (The dongle was too loose and kept falling out when putting it away or taking it out)

Finally (and most importantly)..

  • Fixed the bottom hook. (The hook on the original is the wrong shape; as such, the cover will not properly snap into place. At best, it would be knocked loose during play; at worse, it got jammed and was hard to remove.)

Note: The clips might be a bit tight, try pulling the dongle out from the USB end.

Printer:

XYZ Pro 1.0

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.1

Infill:

10% +

Notes:

Print vertically with the hook towards the print bed and the tongs pointing away. Printing horizontally will result in the remnants of the supports messing up the design (unless your printer/slicer is better than mine, which is entirely possible).

Be careful when removing the supports from around the hook.
